=== [[Wikipedia talk:Deleted articles with freaky titles#rfc_D74FEFE|Wikipedia talk:Deleted articles with freaky titles]] expired 2018-01-29 21:01 ===
* Id: D74FEFE
* User: Knowledgekid87
* Date: 2017-12-30 20:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|817831244|PROP 817831244}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|823018056|PROP 823018056}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Before I begin I want to say that I am all for a funny and creative joke, but we need to draw the line somewhere to avoid this becoming a collection of titles. 

The entries that I removed included:

*Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
*Cccccccccccccccccccccccccccccc

:*Both of these have no humor attached to them other than being "freaky titles". So I did a quick search to find more "freaky titles" and found: Bbbb [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bbbb&action=edit&redlink=1]. Surely this is a "freaky title" but was deleted as pure vandalism.

:*My proposal? Lets limit this list to article names that are creative and/or have a funny backstory to them. If we don't do this then thee list will become a repository for any title that an editor may think is "Freaky". - [[User:Knowledgekid87|Knowledgekid87]] ([[User talk:Knowledgekid87|talk]]) 20:55, 30 December 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Noah Oppenheim#rfc_27659AB|Talk:Noah Oppenheim]] expired 2018-01-30 01:01 ===
* Id: 27659AB
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2018-01-29 21:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|823039925|UNSORTED 823039925}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|823059549|UNSORTED 823059549}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following be added to this article? See discussion [[Talk:Noah_Oppenheim#Weinstein_content|above]] if you like. 

<blockquote>Oppenheim worked with [[Ronan Farrow]] on the conception of the story about the [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations]] and the network supported his investigation for several months, but in the summer of 2017 the network withdrew support as the end of Farrow's contract approached, and Farrow took the story to the ''The New Yorker'' which published it in October after the ''New York Times'' broke the story.  NBC News's failure to publish the story it had developed became a point of criticism and subject of reporting in itself, and Oppenheim defended the news division in response.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Koblin|first1=John|title=How Did NBC Miss Out on a Harvey Weinstein Exposé?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/11/business/media/nbc-news-harvey-weinstein.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=11 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Guthrie|first1=Marisa|title=Why Ronan Farrow's Harvey Weinstein Bombshell Did Not Run on NBC|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-ronan-farrows-harvey-weinstein-bombshell-did-not-run-nbc-1047671|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 11, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Guthrie|first1=Marisa|title=Ronan Farrow, the Hollywood Prince Who Torched the Castle|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/features/ronan-farrow-hollywood-prince-who-torched-castle-1073405|accessdate=11 January 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=|date=10 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Folkenflik|first1=David|last2=Martin|first2=Rachel|title=Decision Not To Publish Weinstein Story Roils NBC|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/10/12/557355945/decision-not-to-publish-weinstein-story-roils-nbc|work=NPR Morning Edition|date=October 12, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Stelter|first1=Brian|title=How NBC gave up Ronan Farrow's explosive Harvey Weinstein scoop|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/10/11/media/nbc-new-yorker-harvey-weinstein/index.html|work=CNN|date=October 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Warren|first1=James|authorlink1=James Warren (journalist)|title=How Badly Did NBC Blow the Weinstein Story?|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/10/how-badly-did-nbc-news-blow-the-weinstein-story|work=Vanity Fair|date=October 13, 2017|language=en|quote=To exhibit a firm grasp of the obvious: One of the finest publications on the planet took a look at whatever Oppenheim took a pass on and felt it was worth the effort. New Yorker chief David Remnick, a polymath with formidable news instincts and an even superior track record, decided there was an irresistible tale to be told. No doubt, there was the not inconsiderable challenge of turning a television piece into a print piece for a magazine whose strength is exactly the nuance and depth that can be incompatible with the structures of TV. But the magazine pulled it off.}}</ref>  </blockquote>
{{reflist-talk}}

-- [[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 21:41, 29 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:So Far Away (Martin Garrix and David Guetta song)#rfc_21DE524|Talk:So Far Away (Martin Garrix and David Guetta song)]] expired 2018-01-30 13:01 ===

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a disagreement with another editor about whether a musical artist's template, which is usually placed at the bottom of their song articles, should be placed at the bottom of this article which is about a song that the artist ([[Ellie Goulding]]) is not a part of, other than on the initial unreleased version (which will never be released because her label negated all agreements and talks). === [[Talk:Zwarte Piet#rfc_C1378DA|Talk:Zwarte Piet]] expired 2018-01-30 20:01 ===

=== [[Talk:Rasta Rasivhenge#rfc_4E225C1|Talk:Rasta Rasivhenge]] expired 2018-01-30 20:01 ===
* Id: 4E225C1
* User: TheMightyPeanut
* Date: 2018-01-15 00:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|820497818|SOC 820497818}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|822535510|SOC 822535510}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How exactly should nationality be defined for a referee? Obviously in the vast number of cases, a referee would represent a country he has citizenship of, or was born in, but this isn't always the case:
* ''Example 1'': [[Steve Walsh (rugby referee)|Steve Walsh]] – born in New Zealand, refereed for New Zealand between 1998 and 2009 and for Australia between 2009 and 2015. Should he be regarded as a New Zealand referee, or as both an Australian and a New Zealand referee?
* ''Example 2'': [[Rasta Rasivhenge]] – born in South Africa, refereed for South Africa since 2011, except in 2014, when he refereed for Australia. Should he be regarded as a South African referee, or as both an Australian and a South African referee?
* ''Example 3'': [[Andrew Brace]] – born in Wales, but refereed for Ireland. Should he be regarded as an Irish referee or a Welsh referee?
If one refers to a referee as an "<country> referee", what does this mean? It it his actual nationality (i.e. what citizenship he has), or is it "sporting nationality" (i.e. which country he represented as a referee). <br/> By my logic:
* If nationality refers to the country the referee is actually from, then Walsh should be classified as a New Zealand referee, Rasivhenge as a South African referee and Brace as a British referee.
* If nationality refers to the the referee's "sporting nationality", then Walsh should be classified as both an Australian and a New Zealand referee, Rasivhenge as both a South African and an Australian referee and Brace as an Irish referee.
Which interpretation should be used to determine a referee's nationality? Feedback greatly welcomed. [[User:TheMightyPeanut|TheMightyPeanut]] ([[User talk:TheMightyPeanut|talk]]) 00:12, 15 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Elizabeth II#rfc_9C8E839|Talk:Elizabeth II]] expired 2018-02-01 01:01 ===
* Id: 9C8E839
* User: nagualdesign
* Date: 2018-01-02 00:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|818172029|MEDIA 818172029}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|818993378|BIO 818993378}}

=== [[Talk:Collapse of the World Trade Center#rfc_43F945D|Talk:Collapse of the World Trade Center]] expired 2018-02-01 20:01 ===
* Id: 43F945D
* User: Thomas Basboll
* Date: 2018-01-02 18:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|818303411|SCI 818303411}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|823526027|SCI 823526027}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'd like to know what people who have not worked on this article think of the difference between the current article and this version [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Collapse_of_the_World_Trade_Center&direction=prev&oldid=797074298]. Note especially the more concise lead and foregrounding of the explanation of the collapse mechanics in the alternative version. Note also that it acknowledges and explicitly dismisses the conspiracy theories that have grown up around this event. My view is that it is more informative and easier to read than the current one and is a step in the direction of [[WP:GA]]. I'm looking forward to hearing what people think.--[[User:Thomas Basboll|Thomas B]] ([[User talk:Thomas Basboll|talk]]) 18:59, 2 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Battle of France#rfc_90B748A|Talk:Battle of France]] expired 2018-02-02 17:01 ===
* Id: 90B748A
* User: Dennis Brown
* Date: 2018-01-24 12:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|822110438|HIST 822110438}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|822110442|TECH 822110442}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|827216882|HIST 827216882}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|827216885|TECH 827216885}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have extended full protection for one more week while the RFC plays out.  Please note, I don't have an opinion here, the question is presented simply to answer the issue at hand.  I will not vote but I will take action if any editor makes personal attacks or is grossly uncivil.

'''Proposal'''

The issue is to '''include''' or '''exclude''' the word "''decisive''" in the infobox as a descriptor of the victory.  The current template strongly discourages the use of a qualifier, but under [[WP:IAR]], it does not prohibit it, thus it is a matter of local consensus.  The template is a stable one so we can assume it has consensus as a general guideline.  The sole question is whether or not this particular article should be an exception to standard practice, for whatever reason.  

At an appropriate time (a week or longer), this will be closed and will provide a clear consensus as to the state of the article, and will serve as demonstration of that consensus until a new RFC demonstrates otherwise.  At that time, anyone edit warring against the consensus will be blocked.  Please use short, policy based reasons in the polling area and not just a vote.  Please keep threaded comments in the "Discussion" area.  

You are encouraged to advertise this RFC on appropriate projects so long as it is a neutral notification and not an endorsement of any side of the issue.  Notifying editors individually will probably be seen as canvassing, so I don't suggest it.  Again, keep it civil, on topic and professional, please.  

'''Until this RFC closes, do not modify the current infobox entry, even if protection expires.  This will be seen as edit warring and will result in a block without warning.'''  This isn't an endorsement of the current version, it is a preventative measure to stop warring until a consensus is reached.  [[User:Dennis Brown|<b>Dennis Brown</b>]] - [[User talk:Dennis Brown|<b>2&cent;</b>]] 12:04, 24 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Unite the Right rally#rfc_1584C31|Talk:Unite the Right rally]] expired 2018-02-02 19:01 ===
* Id: 1584C31
* User: Objective3000
* Date: 2018-01-03 18:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|818475550|BIO 818475550}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|818475600|POL 818475600}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|823679755|BIO 823679755}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|823679765|POL 823679765}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The first paragraph of this article currently contains mention of Trump/Pence signs sourced to one analysis article in a highly [[WP:RS|reliable source]]. The issue with inclusion is [[WP:NPOV]] with particular attention to the following exhortation in [[WP:WEIGHT]]: {{tq| Keep in mind that, in determining proper weight, we consider a viewpoint's prevalence in reliable sources, ''not'' its prevalence among Wikipedia editors or the general public.}} Also note that NPOV states: {{tq|This policy is non-negotiable, and the principles upon which it is based cannot be superseded by other policies or guidelines, nor by editor consensus.}} Earlier discussion can be found at [[Talk:Unite_the_Right_rally#Trump/Pence_signage]]. 

Should the text "Trump/Pence signs" be included in the lead and/or body? Please respond with:

'''Yes, Yes''' {{endash}} Include in the lead and body<br />
'''Yes, No''' {{endash}} Include in the lead only<br />
'''No, Yes''' {{endash}} Include in the body only<br />
'''No, No''' {{endash}} Do not include<br />
[[User:Objective3000|O3000]] ([[User talk:Objective3000|talk]]) 18:24, 3 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Turkey#rfc_ADA8C4E|Talk:Turkey]] expired 2018-02-03 06:01 ===
* Id: ADA8C4E
* User: EtienneDolet
* Date: 2018-01-04 05:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|818560201|POL 818560201}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|823757579|POL 823757579}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
For the word ''Secularism'', which is found in the second sentence of the article, I propose adding a caveat to this bold statement, given that Turkish society has changed considerably over the years.

I propose modifying the sentence to:

{{cquote|'''Turkey is officially secular, despite recent policies by the ruling AKP to create a more Islamic society.''' It is a unitary, parliamentary republic; slated to transition to a presidential system in 2019, following a 2017 referendum.}}

I also strongly suggest to move the secular, unitary, and parliamentary stuff out as the second sentence of the article, and move it to a more appropriate section in the lead, namely the parts of the lead that talk about secularism and government. The first couple of sentences of such an article should not bother talking about referendums and Islamist curtailing of secularism. And just a reminder: I am not going against any RFC conclusion by doing this. ''Secularism'' and ''parliamentary republic'' would still be in the lead, but this modification will give a more accurate description of the developments in Turkey.  [[User:EtienneDolet|Étienne Dolet]] ([[User talk:EtienneDolet|talk]]) 05:24, 4 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Jesse Hamilton#rfc_73C2B3B|Talk:Jesse Hamilton]] expired 2018-02-04 02:01 ===
* Id: 73C2B3B
* User: Kschlot1
* Date: 2018-01-05 01:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|818719192|POL 818719192}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|823895206|POL 823895206}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A new single-purpose account is trying to change the description of Hamilton's NY State Senate caucus, the Independent Democratic Caucus. The essence is that while elected as Democrats, the IDC supports the Republican leadership in the State Senate.  No reliable source disputes that; for example, a NY Times article about the IDC states that "... the Independent Democratic Conference, a coalition of eight Democratic senators who collaborate with Republicans to share leadership in the chamber. By doing so, members of the I.D.C. reap perks and power that they would not normally receive had they remained with the mainline Democrats."

https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/09/nyregion/new-york-independent-democratic-conference-republicans.html?_r=0

I won't break 3RR, but I believe the community will agree that the nature of the IDC is of key importance to Hamilton's political status, and needs to be properly described in the lede  -- as it was until these recent edits. [[User:Kschlot1|Kschlot1]] ([[User talk:Kschlot1|talk]]) 01:10, 5 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Esplanade#rfc_A3A5961|Talk:Esplanade]] expired 2018-02-06 03:01 ===
* Id: A3A5961
* User: Narky Blert
* Date: 2018-01-07 02:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|819261658|HIST 819261658}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|824232850|HIST 824232850}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In most parts of the English-speaking world, [[esplanade]] means what it says here: a walkway, of various kinds.

In West Bengal, Esplanade means specifically [[Esplanade, Kolkata]]; there, that name is [[WP:PTOPIC]]. I have lost count of the number of links to Esplanade which I have corrected. (OK many of them may have been to bus routes{{snd}}but that's another, well-known, issue.) [[Special:WhatLinksHere/Esplanade]] is a disaster area.

'''My proposal'''. In no way do I suggest that Esplanade, Kolkata is WP:PTOPIC. I do suggest that, on a worldwide basis, there is no WP:PTOPIC. I propose: (1) rename Esplanade to [[Esplanade (walkway)]] (2) move the contents of {{noredirect|Esplanade (disambiguation)}} to Esplanade, with the necessary adjustments.

Any such change will get picked up by [[User:DPL bot]], will be logged by it into [[WP:TDD]], and will induce the usual low-level cursing among [[WP:DPL]] regulars about editors who don't [[WP:FIXDABLINKS]]. No matter, we've been there before. [[User:Narky Blert|Narky Blert]] ([[User talk:Narky Blert|talk]]) 02:57, 7 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Flag of Syria#rfc_4606AEF|Talk:Flag of Syria]] expired 2018-02-06 03:01 ===
* Id: 4606AEF
* User: Holy Logician
* Date: 2018-02-05 10:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|824109319|POL 824109319}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|824232853|POL 824232853}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We've had a lengthy, mostly civil, and wholly unresolved discussion on what we should name the current government of Syria in the article. On one side we have editors proposing to name it "Assad government" after the President, with the reasoning that it has lost legitimacy as a government, and is now contested by other organisations claiming to be the de jure government in Syria.
On the other side we have editors (mostly me) positing that naming it after the President is the product of propaganda used by the opposition that wasn't present before the conflict. As such, it may be construed that the phrase is inherently biased and therefore not satisfying Wikipedia content policy.
We'd appreciate any help we can get to reach a compromise on a new consensus. [[User:Holy Logician|Holy Logician]] ([[User talk:Holy Logician|talk]]) 10:28, 5 February 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:209 (number)#rfc_86AA0E2|Talk:209 (number)]] expired 2018-02-06 10:01 ===
* Id: 86AA0E2
* User: Winged Blades of Godric
* Date: 2018-01-07 09:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|819129978|SCI 819129978}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|824270202|SCI 824270202}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The t/p discussants are having a protracted dispute over whether a {{Diff|209 (number)|next|819083035|particular set of mathematical properties/observations}} about 209 are ''worthy-enough'' to be included at [[209 (number)|the article]], which has essentially led to a stalemate.

The previous discussions may be read at [[Talk:209 (number)#Editing|this]], [[Talk:209 (number)#Reference issues|this]] & [[Talk:209 (number)#Importance tags|this]] thread.

The participants are thus requested to kindly solicit their views on <u>whether the facts are significant enough to be kept in the article or not</u>.Please [[WP:NOTVOTE|provide rationales for your comments]].[[User:Winged Blades of Godric|<span style= "color:green">''Winged Blades''</span>]]<sup>[[User talk:Winged Blades of Godric|<span style= "color:green">Godric</span>]]</sup> 09:49, 7 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Music#rfc_9E632C1|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Music]] expired 2018-02-06 16:01 ===
* Id: 9E632C1
* User: Sergecross73
* Date: 2018-01-08 17:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|819313663|MEDIA 819313663}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|824308658|MEDIA 824308658}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the year of release of an album be placed in navigation templates ([[WP:NAV]]) for bands and musicians. 

If you believe "Yes", then that means you'd prefer it to look like [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:P.O.D.&oldid=798241007 this example]. 

If You believe "No", then that means you'd prefer to look like [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:P.O.D.&oldid=798189487 this example]. [[User:Sergecross73|<span style="color:green">Sergecross73</span>]] [[User talk:Sergecross73|<span style="color:teal">msg me</span>]] 17:53, 8 January 2018 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Music#rfc_03BC4BF|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Music]] expired 2018-02-06 16:01 ===
* Id: 03BC4BF
* User: Sergecross73
* Date: 2018-01-08 17:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|819358336|MEDIA 819358336}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|824308658|MEDIA 824308658}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In Wikipedia articles related to general music genre, is it appropriate to put a photo of a specific band in the genre's infobox? 

Hypothetical example, would it be acceptable to go to the [[Pop punk]] article and insert a photo of [[Blink 182]] in the infobox at the top of the article. (This example assumes that they are widely regarded by sources to be pop punk, which they are. The question is not about genre-warring, but about infobox image use.) [[User:Sergecross73|<span style="color:green">Sergecross73</span>]] [[User talk:Sergecross73|<span style="color:teal">msg me</span>]] 17:40, 8 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Tesla Model S#rfc_B717DC7|Talk:Tesla Model S]] expired 2018-02-07 14:01 ===
* Id: B717DC7
* Date: 2018-01-28 04:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|822739016|POLICY 822739016}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|824460908|POLICY 824460908}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{@|Davey2010}} and myself have a disagreement about the date format to be use in references. The article has for a very long time used yyyy-mm-dd in references and MDY in the article text. As given in the section above, my reasoning is that [[MOS:DATEUNIFY]] says all dates in an article should be of the same format <u>but allows for references to use yyyy-mm-dd regardless of the format used in the rest of the article</u>. [[MOS:DATEFORMAT]] backs this up with 'Special rules apply to citations; {{crossref|see {{section link|Wikipedia:Citing sources|Citation style}}}}.' Since yyyy-mm-dd is not allowed to be used in the normal text of the article (ie outside of references and tables), forcing the references to use the same date format as the article effectively disallows yyyy-mm-dd altogether. Why would DATEUNIFY and DATEFORMAT and [[WP:CITESTYLE]] even bother to specify yyyy-mm-dd at all if other guidelines rule it out?

The article has used yyyy-mm-dd for a long time. Davey2010 changed the references to MDY based on his interpretation of [[WP:DATEUNIFY]] on 23 January 2018. I noticed it on 25 January 2018 but there were enough other changes that a simple revert would wipe out too many other changes. On 27 January 2018 I figured out how to change it back to yyyy-mm-dd without affecting intermediate edits via a regular expression script. On 28 January 2018 Davey2010 reverted me again, I reverted him once more and he reverted me once more. Obviously we are in the beginnings of an edit war. I have stopped reverting for the moment not because I believe Davey2010 is right but because an edit war is fruitless.

Note also that both of us agree to [[WP:RETAIN]] (whereby the article should not be changed without consensus). However, Davey2010 believes that RETAIN applies only <u>after</u> his MDY change of 23 January 2018 and not to the status quo for years before that of yyyy-mm-dd. We seem to have a similar disagreement of interpreting [[WP:BRD]] for when to restore the article to during the discussion.

Can others please comment on whether my interpretation of the [[MOS:DATEUNIFY]], [[MOS:DATEFORMAT]] and [[WP:CITESTYLE]] guidelines is correct or whether Davey2010's interpretation is correct? <span style="border:1px solid blue;border-radius:4px;color:blue;box-shadow: 3px 3px 4px grey;">[[User:Stepho-wrs|'''&nbsp;Stepho&nbsp;''']]&nbsp;<span style="font-size:xx-small; vertical-align:top">[[User Talk:Stepho-wrs|talk]]&nbsp;</span></span> 04:54, 28 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Carroll Quigley#rfc_505D497|Talk:Carroll Quigley]] expired 2018-02-08 08:01 ===
* Id: 505D497
* User: Owlsmcgee
* Date: 2018-01-09 07:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|819421109|BIO 819421109}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|819421112|POL 819421112}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|824590523|POL 824590523}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What evidence is needed to support the "conspiracy theorist" tag? Seeking consensus to end an [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carroll_Quigley&action=history edit war] between [[User:Jrheller1|Jrheller1]] and [[User:Tarage|Tarage]] over the use of the term "conspiracy theorist" to describe Carroll Quigley. I came across this page after tracking down a vandal's history (banned user WisdomTooth32) and found the vandal had also removed the "conspiracy theorist" tag. (I think this is coincidental, and for the record, I don't believe Jrheller1 is a sock puppet of the vandal). I have [[Talk:Carroll_Quigley#Conspiracy_Theorist|laid out the case]] (in the talk page section directly above this one) for what I've found in academic searches, but would appreciate additional neutral editors weighing in on what evidence is needed to support the "conspiracy theorist" tag. I also hope that Jrheller1 will cease reverting the category until we generate an actual consensus. Thanks everyone! --[[User:Owlsmcgee|Owlsmcgee]] ([[User talk:Owlsmcgee|talk]]) 07:26, 9 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_DB31B0E|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2018-02-10 00:01 ===
* Id: DB31B0E
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2018-02-09 17:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|824819075|POLICY 824819075}}
* RFC Text:

Following on the [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard&oldid=824816285#Is_Fox_News_a_WP:RS discussion above] (permalink), the following is proposed, as the community stance on Fox News as a source, generally.  Within this, as always, each specific use to support specific content must be evaluated in light of the content policies. 

<blockquote>Fox News is generally as reliable as CNN, NBC, and ABC for mundane facts unrelated to politics, but is deprecated for political subjects. Therefore it should be used with caution regarding politics and its opinions clearly attributed.</blockquote>

--[[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 17:38, 9 February 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Anime and manga#rfc_914E53C|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Anime and manga]] expired 2018-02-10 02:01 ===
* Id: 914E53C
* User: MizukaS
* Date: 2018-01-11 04:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|819844073|MEDIA 819844073}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|824878756|MEDIA 824878756}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am well aware that [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Anime and manga/Archive 69#Inclusion of additional voices in anime voice actor articles|there was a discussion]] about this same topic a while ago. However, due to the fact that it did not up end as a policy, there is still much confusion as to what credits are truly eligible for inclusion. I, for one, think that a vague tweet like [https://twitter.com/CristinaVee/status/573224218357153793 this] is ineligible for inclusion. I do not think that all additional voice credits should be excluded as long as there is a [[wikipedia:Rs|reliable source]] that supports it. These include official cast announcements and credit rolls. [[User:MizukaS|MizukaS]] ([[User talk:MizukaS|talk]]) 04:06, 11 January 2018 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
I have noticed another editor adding links to wikidata for people who fail notability requirements to have articles on wikipedia. In some cases, the he links to wikidata after the article on the person was deleted in [[WP:AfD]]. Before I start reverting his edits, I like to know if this is an acceptable practice. I don't know much about wikidata and what gets included there, but it would seem to me if a person is mentioned in an article (usually as part of a list) and is not notable enough for his/her own article, then there shouldn't be a link to anything. Here's an example of what I'm talking about: [[Mayors of Teaneck, New Jersey]] That article has a lot of links to wikidata. I appreciate input on this.--[[User:Rusf10|Rusf10]] ([[User talk:Rusf10|talk]]) 05:15, 14 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Abkhazia#rfc_06DFFCB|Talk:Abkhazia]] expired 2018-02-11 02:01 ===
* Id: 06DFFCB
* Date: 2018-01-12 01:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|819923837|HIST 819923837}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|819923842|POL 819923842}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|825030430|HIST 825030430}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|825030432|POL 825030432}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The dispute is whether to include the infobox featuring the symbols of the Republic of Abkhazia (such as the flag), which are normally included on all country articles. Abkhazia is a partially-recognized country. Those wanting the infobox in the article argue that it should be in the article because other partially-recognized countries (such as [[South Ossetia]] and [[Republic of Artsakh|Artsakh]]) currently have an infobox. Also, the Abkhazia articles in other languages have the infobox. The argument is that an exception should not be made for Abkhazia (i.e. it shouldn't be the only partially-recognized country without an infobox). Those opposing the infobox say it puts too much weight on the Republic of Abkhazia. But the question then is, where does the infobox go? (Onto a new article titled "Republic of Abkhazia"?) A previous RfC was started on this issue, but that RfC had no consensus. Currently the infobox keeps being added and then reverted by multiple editors. See also the section "Splitting the Abkhazia article" above, which has not resolved the issue so far. 01:45, 12 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Jacob Strandell#rfc_62C3908|Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Jacob Strandell]] expired 2018-02-12 17:01 ===
* Id: 62C3908

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_B644FFF|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2018-02-13 06:01 ===
* Id: B644FFF
* User: SMcCandlish
* Date: 2018-01-24 06:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|822073868|LANG 822073868}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|822073872|POL 822073872}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|822073876|STYLE 822073876}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|827188287|LANG 827188287}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|827188288|POL 827188288}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|827188291|STYLE 827188291}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Issue statement''':<br />
We have arrived at a bewildering profusion of ENGVAR-related templates, the only purpose of which seems to be advancing nationalistic viewpoints.  For those not reading the discussion above this one, the short version is that in an encyclopedic, formal [[Register (socio-linguistics)|register]], there is no meaningful difference between English, Scottish, Irish, Australian, New Zealand, African, Hong Kong, etc., varieties of English, only between [[Commonwealth English]] as a dialect continuum and the North American varieties ([[American English]], and [[Canadian English]] which is a hybrid of American and British/Commonwealth).  Commonwealth English is based on UK-published style guides; there are virtually no reliably published style manuals for Commonwealth dialects that are not produced in England in particular (by contrast, US and Canadian English are the subject of multiple mainstream style guides published in those countries).

'''Concrete proposal''':
* For WP purposes, we would just a {{tlx|Use Commonwealth English}} template with a {{tlx|Use European English}} redirect to it (since Ireland is not part of the Commonwealth at present). That will cover the full gamut of non-North American dialects of English following the style most often called "British".
* We would retain {{tlx|Use American English}} and {{tlx|Use Canadian English}} to cover the North American written dialects.  Canadian is essentially a hybrid of US and British, and there are multiple, reputably published style guides for both US and Canadian writing.
* This would take care of the quiet, categorizing templates in [[:Category:Use English templates]]; the big talk-page and editnotice banner equivalents (e.g. {{tlx|American English}}, etc.) in [[:Category:Varieties of English templates]] would also be merged into a corresponding set of templates.
* Categories used would also, naturally, be merged as needed.
* [[MOS:ENGVAR]] and [[MOS:TIES]] would be clarified and shortened, no longer suggesting that things be written in Pakistani English, etc., which is essentially meaningless with regard to encyclopedic prose.

<span style="white-space:nowrap;font-family:'Trebuchet MS'"> — [[User:SMcCandlish|'''SMcCandlish''']] [[User talk:SMcCandlish|☏]] [[Special:Contributions/SMcCandlish|¢]] 😼 </span> 06:36, 24 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Blue Lives Matter#rfc_057F05A|Talk:Blue Lives Matter]] expired 2018-02-13 07:01 ===
* Id: 057F05A
* Date: 2018-01-26 08:18:00

Should this article include the following text or similar?:
{{tq|Since 1990 the majority of police officers killed by extremist groups, 51 deaths, have been killed by white supremacists and far-right organizations. During the same period left wing and black nationalist extremist groups were responsible for 11 killings.}}
sourced to [http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/national/article196423174.html McClatchy].

If "yes", should the article include this in the lead section or in the body?

08:18, 26 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Raw Power#rfc_C3C0C35|Talk:Raw Power]] expired 2018-02-13 22:01 ===
* Id: C3C0C35
* User: Dan56
* Date: 2018-01-14 21:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|820488385|MEDIA 820488385}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|825524410|MEDIA 825524410}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is an extension of the above discussion that resulted in an impasse between myself and {{ping|Esszet}}. The review in question is [https://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/cg/cgv12b97-97.php this], published in ''[[The Village Voice]]'' as "Consumer Guide", authored by [[Robert Christgau]]. I insist on keeping it credited in the ratings template as ''The Village Voice''--[[WP:MOS|consistent stylistically]] with how the other review sources are credited; by the publication--while Esszet has insisted on re titling both the "Christgau's Record Guide" book review and the Village Voice review as "Christgau's Consumer Guide," an abstract catchall for Christgau's capsule review columns that have long been published in the ''Voice'' and titled as "Consumer Guide" (although they have in more recent years been titled "Expert Witness", in ''MSN Music'' and ''Vice''). Should the review source in this case be credited as ''The Village Voice'' or ''Christgau's Consumer Guide'' (which is the title of a book, in which this review was not originally published in) [[User:Dan56|Dan56]] ([[User talk:Dan56|talk]]) 21:45, 14 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox country#rfc_EEBABDD|Template talk:Infobox country]] expired 2018-02-18 08:01 ===
* Id: EEBABDD
* Date: 2018-01-19 07:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|821247520|STYLE 821247520}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|826286368|STYLE 826286368}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I haven't found any guidelines on this, so I apologize if this topic's been discussed and closed before.

Per [[MOS:CURRENCY]]: {{xt|In country-specific articles, such as Economy of Australia, use the currency of the subject country.}} [...] {{xt|In general, the first mention of a particular currency should use its full, unambiguous signifier (e.g. A$52), with subsequent references using just the appropriate symbol (e.g. $88), unless this would be unclear.}}

A quick browse of infoboxes for some [[OECD#Member_countries|existing countries]] shows no signifier for the type of dollar used to denote their GDP. However, the [[IMF]] seems to be universally cited for the numbers, which notes the amount is in US Dollars. That information is only viewable if the reader opens the reference link. This can be confusing for readers outside the US as the dollar sign is a currency symbol for [[Dollar|multiple countries]], including [[Mexican peso|Mexico's peso]], and en.Wikipedia is the [https://tools.wmflabs.org/langviews/?project=en.wikipedia.org&platform=all-access&agent=user&range=latest-20&sort=views&direction=1&view=list&page=Main_Page most read] of WMF's projects around the world.

I propose adding language to the infobox parameters that ambiguous currency symbols (e.g. [[$]], [[¥]], [[₩]] etc.) should be prepended with the appropriate [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2|ISO code]] as prescribed by [[MOS:CURRENCY]]. The [[Template:Infobox_country#Examples|Examples]] and [[Template:Infobox_country#TemplateData|TemplateData]] section on this infobox's page should show currency code examples like [[US$]]10.5 billion or [[HK$]]10.5 billion, dependent of course on what currency the reference uses. Unambiguous symbols, like the Indian rupee ([[₹]]) should just be wikilinked without the ISO code. - <span style="text-shadow: 4px 4px 15px #0099FF, -4px -4px 15px #99FF00;"><b>[[User:GrapefruitSculpin|GS]]</b></span> ⋙ <span style="text-shadow: 4px 4px 15px #FF9900, -4px -4px 15px #FF0099;">[[User_talk:GrapefruitSculpin|☎]]</span> 07:32, 19 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_F2141EF|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2018-02-18 17:01 ===
* Id: F2141EF
* User: Cyberpower678#top
* Date: 2018-02-11 19:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|825152565|PROP 825152565}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|825161295|PROP 825161295}}
* RFC Text:

This topic has seen a lot of debate, but I think we might want to consider turning off the function that leaves messages on talk pages.

See [[user:InternetArchiveBot]] for context. [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Namibian_Port_Authority&oldid=825153665 This talk page shows a typical instance] of the bot's messaging process, which it does after redirecting a dead link to an archived copy of a dead web page hosted at the [[Internet Archive]]. The bot has posted hundreds of thousands of these messages on various Wikipedia article talk pages since 2016.

Why? 
*IABot's error rate has dropped to near negligible numbers.
*Users really interested in checking the edit, will do so without being asked to.
*If the bot did make an error, with IABot's newest upgrade in v1.6, simply reverting the bot is enough to report a bad edit as a false positive.

Question for you guys, should I turn off the bot's messaging feature? <small class="autosigned">—&nbsp;Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Cyberpower678|Cyberpower678]] ([[User talk:Cyberpower678#top|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Cyberpower678|contribs]]) 19:51, 11 February 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:March 14, 1891, lynchings#rfc_5BFC403|Talk:March 14, 1891, lynchings]] expired 2018-02-18 18:01 ===
* Id: 5BFC403
* User: MopTop

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{Wiktionary|lynching}}
See previous section. We're on the verge of an edit war, and I'm starting to get pretty exasperated. People seem to be offended by Gambino's claim that this was the largest lynching in American history, but he based that claim on the definition of lynching in the Encyclopedia Brittanica and the NAACP's records on lynching. I also cited a page on the Library of Congress website that says the same thing. If he's wrong, so be it, but you have to do the work and show your sources. Don't just try to browbeat me into submission. [[User:MopTop|--MopTop]] ([[User talk:MopTop|talk]]) 17:32, 19 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Star Wars: The Last Jedi#rfc_6B47418|Talk:Star Wars: The Last Jedi]] expired 2018-02-18 22:01 ===
* Id: 6B47418
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2018-01-19 21:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|821344444|MEDIA 821344444}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|821351825|SOC 821351825}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|826397550|MEDIA 826397550}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|826397643|SOC 826397643}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi, all. Per [[Talk:Star Wars: The Last Jedi#Should we include an Audience response section?|an RfC]], editors (myself included) have worked on a draft at [[Draft:Star Wars Last Jedi audience response]] and its talk page. We are just about done, but there are remaining disagreements and we need comments from other editors to finally get this material into the article. The main disagreements are the following: There [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Draft_talk:Star_Wars_Last_Jedi_audience_response&oldid=821321762#Opening_line is debate] on whether or not to present the "divisive" aspect first and whether or not it is [[WP:Due]] or WP:Undue. With regard to the parentage aspect, there is [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Draft_talk:Star_Wars_Last_Jedi_audience_response&oldid=821321762#Rey_as_a_Skywalker debate] on whether or not, in order to give give an example instead of being vague, we should mention that many fans were expecting [[Rey (Star Wars)|Rey]] to be [[Luke Skywalker|Luke's]] daughter. Or whether we should mention a few examples. And there is debate on whether or not to plainly state that many fans felt that Luke's actions in ''The Last Jedi'' contrasted his previous heroic portrayal or to instead state that many fans felt that he should have been portrayed more heroically; how to word this can be worked out later. There was also [[alt-right]] debates, but we have kept that material out of the draft. I present '''three versions''' below. Obviously, none of these versions mean that the section cannot be edited further afterward. Coming to a consensus on one of the versions simply means that we can finally move forward. [[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 21:17, 19 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Knights of Columbus#rfc_C6BD228|Talk:Knights of Columbus]] expired 2018-02-21 13:01 ===
* Id: C6BD228
* User: GreenMeansGo
* Date: 2018-01-22 14:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|821771063|POL 821771063}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|821946270|RELI 821946270}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|826870031|POL 826870031}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|826870035|RELI 826870035}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
* '''Q:''' Should the article mention [[Proposition 8]] specifically in the lead?
*'''Note:''' Originally summoned bot. I'm boldly cutting short the previous RfC and opening one that is specific enough to reach an actionable consensus. Per [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Knights_of_Columbus&diff=821766392&oldid=821762076 this comment], this one issue seems to be a a particular enough sticking point where consensus can fall clearly one way or the other, and one side or the other is going to need to accept it and move on. [[User:GreenMeansGo|<span style="font-family:Impact"><span style="color:#07CB4B">G</span><span style="color:#449351">M</span><span style="color:#35683d">G</span></span>]][[User talk:GreenMeansGo|<sup style="color:#000;font-family:Impact">talk</sup>]]  14:51, 22 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Military Sealift Command#rfc_8B62314|Talk:Military Sealift Command]] expired 2018-02-22 02:01 ===
* Id: 8B62314
* User: Coffee Atoms
* Date: 2018-01-23 01:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|821891128|SCI 821891128}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|822034200|POL 822034200}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|822034203|STYLE 822034203}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|826977009|SCI 826977009}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|826977011|POL 826977011}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|826977012|STYLE 826977012}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In 2015 the CNO and SecNav renamed multiple classes, including changing designations for JHSV's to Expeditionary Fast Transport (EPF), Mobile Landing Platform (MLP) to Expeditionary Transfer Dock (ESD), and the Afloat Forward Staging Base (AFSB) variant of the MLP to Expeditionary Sea Base (ESB). Expeditionary Sea Base (ESB) is the correct designation for ESB-class vessels and there is no need to edit it to previous or outdated names.  [[User:Coffee Atoms|Coffee Atoms]] ([[User talk:Coffee Atoms|talk]]) 01:17, 23 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Coachella Valley Church#rfc_0E8F118|Talk:Coachella Valley Church]] expired 2018-02-22 17:01 ===
* Id: 0E8F118
* User: NaturaNaturans
* Date: 2018-01-23 16:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|821963097|POL 821963097}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|822062921|RELI 822062921}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Various names are editing this article to lead with details about its operation as a Church. However, the news sources themselves question whether or not it is actually a marijuana dispensary operating as a Church and the City is trying to shut down their operations. The notability of this article is due based on this dispute between the City which calls it a marijuana dispensary and the 'Church'. I edited it to be more even handed and include details of the dispute in the lead but keep getting reverted by various names (who may or may not be the same person or group trying to push their side of this dispute). Its current form is biased and misleading trying to bury the claims that this newly formed 'Church' is actually a marijuana dispensary. === [[Talk:The Satanic Temple#rfc_FDA8BE8|Talk:The Satanic Temple]] expired 2018-02-23 02:01 ===
* Id: FDA8BE8
* User: Seanbonner
* Date: 2018-01-24 01:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|822042473|RELI 822042473}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|827152494|RELI 827152494}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Until recently this article has been about an organization called The Satanic Temple whose members were [[Satanists]], recently it was been decided through editor consensus that The Satanic Temple is not only an organization but also it's own religion, whose members are also called Satanists. As this is a new stand alone religion this Satanism is different from the pre-existing religion of Satanism. As it so happens there is an existing disambiguation page [[Satanism_(disambiguation)]] to clarify uses of the term Satanism & Satanist. On the top of [[Satanism]] is a [[WP:hatnote]] that says "For other uses, see [[Satanism (disambiguation)]]." the question is if a similar link should now be included at the top of this article. [[User:Seanbonner|Seanbonner]] ([[User talk:Seanbonner|talk]]) 01:02, 24 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers#rfc_2AC8F9A|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers]] expired 2018-02-23 06:01 ===
* Id: 2AC8F9A
* User: SMcCandlish
* Date: 2018-01-24 05:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|822073867|ECON 822073867}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|822073869|SCI 822073869}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|822073875|SOC 822073875}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|822073876|STYLE 822073876}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|827181495|ECON 827181495}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|827181499|SCI 827181499}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|827181533|SOC 827181533}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|827181534|STYLE 827181534}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Presently, [[MOS:NUMS]] includes:
{{talk quote|Sometimes, the variety of English used in an article may necessitate the use of a numbering system other than the Western thousands-based system. For example, the South Asian numbering system is conventionally used in South Asian English. In those situations, link the first spelled-out instance of each quantity (e.g. [[crore]], which yields: crore).}}
This is followed by three more bullet points of [[WP:CREEP]] about ''[[crore]]''.  The lead sentence of this is just patently false; nothing necessitates the use of alternative numbering systems.  Proof that Indian English doesn't do so abounds (including with regard to Indian currency) [https://www.google.com/search?num=20&lr=&as_qdr=all&q=Rs+60+million+site%3Ain+-convert+-imdb+-wikipedia+-wiki+-crore+-cr], [https://www.google.com/search?num=20&lr=&as_qdr=all&q=billion+site%3Ain+-convert+-imdb+-wikipedia+-wiki], [https://www.google.com/search?num=20&lr=&as_qdr=all&q=27+million+site%3Ain+-convert+-imdb+-wikipedia+-wiki], [https://www.google.com/search?num=20&lr=&as_qdr=all&q=80+million+site%3Ain+-convert+-imdb+-wikipedia+-wiki] etc., etc.

'''I propose that this be deleted''' and replaced with a) short advice against use of crore in Wikipedia articles, unless conversion is provided to Western numbers, and b) retaining the advice against using "1,00,00,000" for "10,000,000". 

'''Rationale''': I do not believe the present wording has actual consensus, and crore are rarely used in our articles even on Indian subjects.  Some small number of Indian editors have somehow gotten MoS to be permissive about crore, despite it being non-English and meaning nothing to most anyone outside that part of the world, and despite English-speakers of India having no problem with "ten million" (or "10,000,000", "10mil", "10M", etc.)<br /><span style="white-space:nowrap;font-family:'Trebuchet MS'"> — [[User:SMcCandlish|'''SMcCandlish''']] [[User talk:SMcCandlish|☏]] [[Special:Contributions/SMcCandlish|¢]] 😼 </span> 05:08, 24 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:"Polish death camp" controversy#rfc_DCF570D|Talk:"Polish death camp" controversy]] expired 2018-02-23 17:01 ===
* Id: DCF570D
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|825372116|LANG 825372116}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|825372122|POL 825372122}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|825554825|LANG 825554825}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|825632134|POL 825632134}}
=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Music#rfc_8AA22ED|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Music]] expired 2018-02-23 18:01 ===
* Id: 8AA22ED
* User: Jax 0677
* Date: 2018-01-24 17:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|822149313|MEDIA 822149313}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|827259499|MEDIA 827259499}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have been given numerous amounts of feedback regarding the placement of ranking charts within music albums.  I have stated that per [[WP:IDEALSTUB]], that sufficient context shall be given in placing ranking charts within an article, even if the chart is almost identical to a chart table that exists in an artist, ensemble, or discography page, and might not be formatted in an ideal manner.  Some of these music ranking charts are difficult to manipulate, therefore, leeway should be permitted to persons who wish to copy and paste the information from one article to another, so long as they update the references to an appropriate access date.  If the chart is identical, the information is still there, even if the table contains empty columns.  Additionally, I have been scolded about putting music ranking charts for singles in an album article, if the artist/ensemble/discography page already has these rankings.  I think that users should be permitted to add these to album articles. --[[User:Jax 0677|Jax 0677]] ([[User talk:Jax 0677|talk]]) 17:10, 24 January 2018 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the "Bus service" section have a [[User:Titanosaurus/sandbox#Oakland Coliseum station bus service table:|table]] that is somewhat similar to the one seen in good articles [[Coney Island–Stillwell Avenue (New York City Subway)#Bus terminal|Coney Island–Stillwell Avenue]] and [[Flushing–Main Street (IRT Flushing Line)#Bus service|Flushing–Main Street]]? [[AC Transit]] views the station as one of its major [http://www.actransit.org/transit-center-maps-and-information/ transit centers], serving 12 routes (most of which are feeder routes terminating at the station) that carry over 2 million passengers a year combined ([https://www.alamedactc.org/files/managed/Document/16546/Existing_Conditions_Market_Analysis_Task2.pdf Source 1 for that statement, starts at Page A-1]) ([http://www.mobilityplanners.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/AlamedaTDM_FinalReport_Final_2012_03_20.pdf Source 2 for that statement, Page 20]). My recent attempt at clarifying this issue using the [[Wikipedia:Dispute resolution noticeboard/Archive 160#Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Trains#Oakland Coliseum station|dispute resolution]] process failed due to a lack of participation, so hopefully this process can finally bring me some clarification for the future. === [[Wikipedia talk:Notability (events)#rfc_3A40A05|Wikipedia talk:Notability (events)]] expired 2018-02-26 23:01 ===
* Id: 3A40A05
* User: ජපස
* Date: 2018-01-27 22:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|822690562|POLICY 822690562}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|827822867|POLICY 827822867}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia%3ANotability_%28events%29&type=revision&diff=821224570&oldid=821180474 this edit] be reinstated? [[User:ජපස|jps]] ([[User talk:ජපස|talk]]) 22:08, 27 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:COI#rfc_E0B3DF2|Template talk:COI]] expired 2018-02-27 01:01 ===
* Id: E0B3DF2
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2018-01-28 00:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|822706635|POLICY 822706635}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|827836927|POLICY 827836927}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the instructions for [[:Template:COI]] include the following underlined language?

<blockquote>Like the other neutrality-related tags, if you place this tag, you should promptly start a discussion on the article's talk page to explain what is non-neutral about the article. If you do not start this discussion, then any editor <u>[[WP:COI|without a conflict of interest]]</u> is justified in removing the tag without warning.  Be careful not to violate the policy against [[WP:OUTING]] users who have not publicly self-disclosed their identities on the English Wikipedia.</blockquote>

-- [[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 00:29, 28 January 2018 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
'''In general''', should articles about anime media use the disambiguator {{xt|(anime)}}, rather than more general ones like {{xt|([animated] TV series)}} or {{xt|(film)}} or, more broadly, {{xt|(franchise)}}? There is some disagreement over whether an earlier discussion, [[WP:VPP#RfC: Is "telenovela" a suitable disambiguator?]] ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Village_pump_(policy)&oldid=823178828#RfC:_Is_%22telenovela%22_a_suitable_disambiguator? permalink]), is applicable.

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_F0D4140|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2018-02-27 04:01 ===
* Id: F0D4140
* User: Narutolovehinata5
* Date: 2018-01-28 03:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|822726678|BIO 822726678}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|822726691|POLICY 822726691}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|822726693|PROP 822726693}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|827858881|BIO 827858881}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|827858940|POLICY 827858940}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|827858943|PROP 827858943}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per previous discussions over at [[Wikipedia talk:Days of the year]], it seems that there is some level of support for some kind of inclusion criteria for what articles to include on the Births and Deaths sections. There are some concerns that these sections are too-Western centric (i.e. people from North America or Europe are over-represented).

The question now is: should we have some kind of guideline for inclusion in Births and Dates articles? Or is the status-quo fine? In my case, my pet proposal is that a proposed inclusion criteria would be similar to what's currently done at [[WP:DYK]], where no more than half of each set can be about US-related topics. Though of course, other editors are free to propose other proposals here. [[User:Narutolovehinata5|Narutolovehinata5]] <sup>[[User talk:Narutolovehinata5|t]][[Special:Contributions/Narutolovehinata5|c]][[WP:CSD|csd]][[Special:Newpages|new]]</sup> 03:16, 28 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Noah Oppenheim#rfc_EE73D96|Talk:Noah Oppenheim]] expired 2018-02-28 22:01 ===

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following be added to the article in place of the current statement on the topic:

*Oppenheim was one of the NBC executives involved in the decision to fire Matt Lauer after [[Matt_Lauer#Sexual_misconduct_allegations|sexual harassment claims were made]] against the Today Show host. <ref>{{cite news|last1=Koblin|first1=John|title=After Firing Matt Lauer, NBC Executives Move to Control the Damage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/01/business/media/matt-lauer-firing-nbc-news.html|work=The New York Times|date=1 December 2017}}</ref>

Plus, of course, it's also on [[Matt Lauer]]. In order to explore this topic fairly, you need a bunch of context. You also have both critical and supportive statements about NBC News's response. But if you go down this route of explaining the situation fairly, it becomes very COATRACK for a blp. [[User:BC1278|BC1278]] ([[User talk:BC1278|talk]]) 22:09, 15 February 2018 (UTC)}}

Should the following be added to this article? See discussion [[Talk:Noah_Oppenheim#Weinstein_content|above]] if you like. 

<blockquote>Oppenheim worked with [[Ronan Farrow]] on the conception of the story about the [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations]] and the network supported his investigation for several months, but in the summer of 2017 the network withdrew support as the end of Farrow's contract approached, and Farrow took the story to the ''The New Yorker'' which published it in October after the ''New York Times'' broke the story.  NBC News's failure to publish the story it had developed became a point of criticism and subject of reporting in itself, and Oppenheim defended the news division in response.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Koblin|first1=John|title=How Did NBC Miss Out on a Harvey Weinstein Exposé?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/11/business/media/nbc-news-harvey-weinstein.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=11 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Guthrie|first1=Marisa|title=Why Ronan Farrow's Harvey Weinstein Bombshell Did Not Run on NBC|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-ronan-farrows-harvey-weinstein-bombshell-did-not-run-nbc-1047671|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 11, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Guthrie|first1=Marisa|title=Ronan Farrow, the Hollywood Prince Who Torched the Castle|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/features/ronan-farrow-hollywood-prince-who-torched-castle-1073405|accessdate=11 January 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=|date=10 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Folkenflik|first1=David|last2=Martin|first2=Rachel|title=Decision Not To Publish Weinstein Story Roils NBC|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/10/12/557355945/decision-not-to-publish-weinstein-story-roils-nbc|work=NPR Morning Edition|date=October 12, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Stelter|first1=Brian|title=How NBC gave up Ronan Farrow's explosive Harvey Weinstein scoop|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/10/11/media/nbc-new-yorker-harvey-weinstein/index.html|work=CNN|date=October 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Warren|first1=James|authorlink1=James Warren (journalist)|title=How Badly Did NBC Blow the Weinstein Story?|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/10/how-badly-did-nbc-news-blow-the-weinstein-story|work=Vanity Fair|date=October 13, 2017|language=en|quote=To exhibit a firm grasp of the obvious: One of the finest publications on the planet took a look at whatever Oppenheim took a pass on and felt it was worth the effort. New Yorker chief David Remnick, a polymath with formidable news instincts and an even superior track record, decided there was an irresistible tale to be told. No doubt, there was the not inconsiderable challenge of turning a television piece into a print piece for a magazine whose strength is exactly the nuance and depth that can be incompatible with the structures of TV. But the magazine pulled it off.}}</ref>  </blockquote>

=== [[Talk:A Wizard of Earthsea#rfc_DE4095D|Talk:A Wizard of Earthsea]] expired 2018-03-01 02:01 ===
* Id: DE4095D
* User: Clarityfiend
* Date: 2018-01-30 01:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|823068742|STYLE 823068742}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|828189238|STYLE 828189238}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[User:Vanamonde93]] and I have a disagreement about what is acceptable in synopses (see "Disputed changes" section above), specifically:

<blockquote>
Here Ged realizes that the shadow has always been a part of his own spirit. Naming it with his own name, he merges with the shadow creature, understanding and accepting it as part of himself, and thus healing himself.{{sfn|Cadden|2005|p=80}}{{sfn|Bernardo|Murphy|2006|pp=98–99}}
</blockquote>

{{reflist-talk}}

I believe that this violates [[MOS:PLOT]]: "the plot summary must not present interpretations of the creators' intent. [...]  Interpretation of the plot taken from reliable sources can be included elsewhere in the article to provide additional information." The fact that it requires two sources to back it up demonstrates, in my opinion, that this is the case here. Author [[Ursula K. Le Guin]] never reveals the exact nature of the shadow creature, leaving that to the reader's imagination. She also, as far as I can recall, doesn't refer to any "spirit" whatsoever. [[User:Clarityfiend|Clarityfiend]] ([[User talk:Clarityfiend|talk]]) 01:07, 30 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Princess Eugenie of York#rfc_DB0834D|Talk:Princess Eugenie of York]] expired 2018-03-01 17:01 ===
* Id: DB0834D
* Date: 2018-01-30 16:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|823164105|BIO 823164105}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|828280523|BIO 828280523}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been some sort of edit war going on this page ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Princess_Eugenie_of_York&type=revision&diff=822383747&oldid=822383728 1], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Princess_Eugenie_of_York&type=revision&diff=822384685&oldid=822384263 2], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Princess_Eugenie_of_York&type=revision&diff=823146209&oldid=822780270 3]) over the inclusion or exclusion of a claim by Martin Farr, a senior history lecturer at Newcastle University, who had said that Princess Eugenie was initially rejected, and that the only reason she got approved was due to her royal status. To User:Richard naar it sounds like a rumor, but rumors and conspiracies may become notable if they make their way to the national newspapers. We even have articles about different sorts of conspiracies here on Wikipedia. I ask the users and readers to take a look at [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2017/07/17/princess-eugenie-rejected-university-given-place-realised-royal/ this article] by The Daily Telegraph and decide whether we should include these information in the article or not. <span style="font:'Pristina'">[[user:Keivan.f|<span style="color: #1E7HDC">Keivan.f</span>]]</span><span style="font:'Pristina'"><sup>[[user_talk:Keivan.f|<span style="color: purple">Talk</span>]]</sup></span> 16:55, 30 January 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Dana Loesch#rfc_EDDBB6E|Talk:Dana Loesch]] expired 2018-03-01 22:01 ===
* Id: EDDBB6E
* Date: 2018-02-28 07:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|828051955|BIO 828051955}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|828051956|HIST 828051956}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|828051959|POL 828051959}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|828323852|BIO 828323852}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|828323854|HIST 828323854}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|828323859|POL 828323859}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The primary argument here for noninclusion has appeared to be that such mentions by the blp's subject, found accompanying political commentary published at partisan opinion platforms (Breitbart, FNC, TheBlaze, the conservative imprint at Penguin Books, her own web platforms such as on Twitter), render such sourcing [[wp:BIASED]], therefore no such sourcing ought be resorted to within a blp. The primary argument pro-inclusion has seemed to be that, despite considerations of partisan media, within the spirit of [[wp:SELFPUB]], a subject is a reliable source about herself.--07:07, 28 February 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of Trump–Russia dossier allegations#rfc_ABDF2E8|Talk:List of Trump–Russia dossier allegations]] expired 2018-03-02 14:01 ===
* Id: ABDF2E8
* Date: 2018-02-10 17:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|824968069|POL 824968069}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|828429447|POL 828429447}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Merge This article &rarr; [[Trump–Russia dossier]]'''

This article doesn't really have a good reason to stand alone other than length, and length is a problem that can be addressed with formatting and proper prose integration. If we merged this article into [[Trump–Russia dossier|the main article]], we could trim out all but the dry text outlining the allegation (a step that would, I believe, address many of the NPOV complaints made here), leaving the commentary to the main parts of the article. This could be formatted in a number of ways that would not make that article over-long. Indeed, much of the dry text describing the allegations could be trimmed significantly, as the details will have been given in the main body already. I mean, this article is about ''the contents'' of the dossier. I don't see any need to fork that off from the main article. <span style="text-shadow:grey 0.118em 0.118em 0.118em; class=texhtml">[[User:MjolnirPants|<font color="green">'''ᛗᛁᛟᛚᚾᛁᚱPants'''</font>]] [[User_talk:MjolnirPants|<small>Tell me all about it.</small>]]</span> 17:35, 10 February 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Real News Update#rfc_6F46898|Talk:Real News Update]] expired 2018-03-02 18:01 ===
* Id: 6F46898
* User: DrFleischman
* Date: 2018-02-05 19:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|824186869|POL 824186869}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|828460989|POL 828460989}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following sentence be kept or removed?

:{{tq|Some stories that Lara Trump claimed were ignored by the media, such as the plans of [[Foxconn]] to build a factory in Wisconsin and the donation of President's Trump's salary to the [[United States Department of Education|Department for Education]], had in fact previously been reported by news outlets.}}
The cited source is: 
* {{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/08/02/media/trump-real-news/index.html |title=Trump launches 'real news' Facebook series to combat mainstream media |author=Dylan Byers |date=August 2, 2017 |work=CNN |accessdate=August 2, 2017}}
Please !vote with either '''Keep''' or '''Remove'''. --[[User:DrFleischman|Dr. Fleischman]] ([[User talk:DrFleischman|talk]]) 19:33, 5 February 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Film#rfc_81F0AE4|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Film]] expired 2018-03-03 23:01 ===
* Id: 81F0AE4
* User: Hoverfish
* Date: 2018-03-01 14:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|828264326|MEDIA 828264326}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|833436158|MEDIA 833436158}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Since last year, [[User:‎Michael 182]], also as [[User:TwentySteps]] (blocked) and via various IP edits (some blocked for socking), has been splitting several film award articles that were previously arranged in one whole table, most of them sortable, into tables by decades. Venice Festival awards: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Golden_Lion&type=revision&diff=808058639&oldid=806091076], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Silver_Lion&type=revision&diff=808062802&oldid=799768892], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Volpi_Cup_for_Best_Actor&type=revision&diff=808066192&oldid=803129364], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Volpi_Cup_for_Best_Actress&type=revision&diff=808099890&oldid=803130412]. Berlin Festival awards: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Golden_Bear&type=revision&diff=807743545&oldid=800928169], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Silver_Bear_for_Best_Director&type=revision&diff=807958060&oldid=800929501], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Silver_Bear_for_Best_Actor&type=revision&diff=807960820&oldid=801812885], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Silver_Bear_for_Best_Actress&type=revision&diff=808049871&oldid=801819695]. He has also done various changes in Academy Awards and Primetime Emmy Awards which are outside of my scope of interest in films. Note also that I have not opposed the division by decades in director and actor awards as this is also outside my focus of interest, plus I find no meaningful sortability damaged in so splitting them.

From several discussions I have participated or just followed in WP:Film, I am aware that by longstanding consensus the preferred format for presenting film award lists, is by using one stortable table. Splitting such a table to smaller tables by decades (sortable or not) disables any meaningful sortability throughout the whole list. If split by decades, one cannot get either a full alphabetical list of Directors or of Films that won a certain award any longer. Since the user claims that there is not sufficient evidence that such consensus exists, I am doing here a formal RfC to have some consensus on this issue clearly found in one place, also for future reference. 1. Should the film award articles be kept in one sortable table or split in decades? 2. Should director and actress/actor awards be kept in one sortable table or split in decades? [[User:Hoverfish|Hoverfish]] <small>[[User talk:Hoverfish|Talk]]</small> 14:27, 1 March 2018 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Film#rfc_6921A5F|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Film]] expired 2018-03-03 23:01 ===
* Id: 6921A5F
* User: JDDJS
* Date: 2018-02-01 22:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the narrator section in the infobox for films be reserved solely for documentaries or should it also be used for films like [[A Christmas Story]] in which an actor who doesn't physically appear in the film narrates sections of the film? The MOS currently does not address this issue, so whatever the consensus is here, MOS should be changed to reflect that. [[User:JDDJS|JDDJS]] ([[User talk:JDDJS|talk]]) 22:19, 1 February 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Did you know#rfc_8644A56|Wikipedia talk:Did you know]] expired 2018-03-04 02:01 ===
* Id: 8644A56
* User: Vanamonde93
* Date: 2018-02-11 17:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|825132945|POLICY 825132945}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|828676913|POLICY 828676913}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The role of admins in the DYK process as defined in the instructions, and the role as practiced, differ widely. Moreover, different admins treat their role differently, and based on past discussions, have widely divergent views on what the role should be. For folks unfamiliar with the process, admins are required to move approved DYK hooks from Prep areas to Queues. The question here is what, if any, further checks admins are required to perform during this process.  

Since there are many possible combinations here, I have structured this to permit maximum flexibility in the outcome. Therefore, please feel free to add additional checks that you think admins are required to do, that I may have left out. [[User:Vanamonde93|Vanamonde]] ([[User talk:Vanamonde93|talk]]) 17:27, 11 February 2018 (UTC)}}
