=== [[Talk:Abiogenesis#rfc_2EEB6A4|Talk:Abiogenesis]] expired 2018-11-14 15:01 ===
* Id: 2EEB6A4
* User: Inowen
* Date: 2018-11-14 05:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|868761824|SCI 868761824}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|868761825|RELI 868761825}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|868761826|POLICY 868761826}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|868802916|SCI 868802916}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|868802920|RELI 868802920}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|868802925|POLICY 868802925}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The issue isn't one of Creation Science but one of [[WP:NPOV|neutrality]], where the language in the article that declares that:
:"Abiogenesis or origin of life <u>is the natural process by which life arises from non-living matter</u> 
is not NPOV because it asserts a thesis that life comes about through an "[[up from the muck]]" process only, which is vastly overreaching and overstated, and categorically rules out "[[down from the stars]]" theories. Rowan claims science is agnostic, then the POV here is that science and the article should remain agnostic and not atheistic. 

(An editor Apokryltaros (labelled as Mr Fink) claimed the right of closing the above discussion, which was improper in my view. He also removed my comment from his talk page.[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk:Apokryltaros&diff=868747942&oldid=868747747]) -[[User:Inowen|Inowen]] ([[User talk:Inowen|nlfte]]) 05:40, 14 November 2018 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Science#rfc_FD8DA8F|Talk:Science]] expired 2018-11-14 15:01 ===
* Id: FD8DA8F
* User: Inowen
* Date: 2018-11-11 04:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|868761824|SCI 868761824}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|868802916|SCI 868802916}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
:''Was'' "Science as a compendium of revelations from God "
There is an idea of science as being exclusively a revelation from nature, but the idea of science as being the revelations of God has some history in philosophy, and in the religionist's accommodating usage of "philosophy" and "science" (note similarity in meaning) as fitting in a Holy perspective. For example, claims and references to claims like "[in] the prolegomena to Aristotle’s Physica, [Girolamo] [[Girolamo Zanchi|Zanchi]] makes the case that philosophy ultimately comes to man by divine revelation"[https://calvinistinternational.com/2017/02/10/zanchis-aristotle-4-philosophy-as-revelation/]. 

Some might read that as philsophy and not science, but the connection between science and philosophy is deep, and of late is perhaps misconveyed as distant, such that philosophy connotes soft and unrigourous research which includes the possibility of God, while "science" has become a code word for 'atheistic research only.' I suggested at [[WP:VP/I#Articles which ask a question|WP:VP/I]] that we have articles which ask questions, but first perhaps a single article on the "[[Big questions]]" is required. One of the big questions we know by heart and mind is "[[is there a God?]]" From that basis, treatment of God as a possibility can be asked as a question, and then the treatment of God as an object for scientific proof. Dear science, can there be <s>some connection between science and philosophy and religion?</s> -[[User:Inowen|Inowen]] ([[User talk:Inowen|nlfte]]) 04:16, 11 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Baraboo High School#rfc_B114969|Talk:Baraboo High School]] expired 2018-11-14 17:01 ===
* Id: B114969
* User: John from Idegon
* Date: 2018-11-14 05:04:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As this discussion is rapidly spinning out of control (witness multiple sections being opened on the same topic and attempts to centralize the discussion being reverted), it appears a more formal (and widely publicized) solution is in order.

The question is: 

'''What if anything should we include at this time on the "Nazi salute controversy"?'''

It's also fairly clear we have four choices:
#Some variation (subject to discussion on the finer points) of what existed [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Baraboo_High_School&diff=prev&oldid=868681256 here].
#Nothing.
#Nothing for now, revisiting in say three months so we can accurately gauge the enduring nature of this information.
#A brief discussion of the school itself's role in this.

Please indicate your preferences in order from the one that most suits your position to the least suitable, along with your arguments.

Thanks. [[User:John from Idegon|John from Idegon]] ([[User talk:John from Idegon|talk]]) 05:04, 14 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/Featured quality source review RfC#rfc_D7277D2|Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/Featured quality source review RfC]] expired 2018-11-15 09:01 ===
* Id: D7277D2
* Date: 2018-10-16 08:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|864462582|PROP 864462582}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|864554672|PROJ 864554672}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|868930750|PROJ 868930750}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|868930752|PROP 868930752}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{nutshell|This is a proposal for a separate source review according to the two existing criteria ''before'' an article is nominated to FAC or FLC. The aims are to avoid wasting other compliance reviewing when sourcing is later found to be deficient, to highlight the importance of good sourcing practice at the forum, and to improve sourcing skills in the community.}}

Currently a nominated article may be declared to be of "featured" quality: through the [[WP:FAC|featured article candidates]] page (FAC) or [[WP:FLC|the equivalent page for lists]] (FLC).  Both FAC and FLC require at least one review to address sources before a candidate can be promoted.

This RfC proposes a new, featured quality review process: featured quality source reviews (FSR).  The sections below give details about the process.  Please add comments to the discussion section, and indicate '''support''' or '''oppose''' in the poll section below. 08:11, 16 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of vegetarians#rfc_5BBC05B|Talk:List of vegetarians]] expired 2018-11-15 11:01 ===
* Id: 5BBC05B
* User: Betty Logan
* Date: 2018-10-16 10:30:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
An editor keeps moving the Hitler entry from the main list to the "disputed vegetarians" section, typified by [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_vegetarians&diff=864280354&oldid=864253748 this edit]. I took the dispute to [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view/Noticeboard#Disputing Hitler's vegetarianism]], but there was only a single impartial response and the other party does not believe this constitutes a consensus. Therefore I have started this RFC to establish whether Hitler be added to '''disputed vegetarian''' section or remain in the '''vegetarian''' section? [[User:Betty Logan|Betty Logan]] ([[User talk:Betty Logan|talk]]) 10:30, 16 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Sci-Hub#rfc_63B71D8|Talk:Sci-Hub]] expired 2018-11-15 13:01 ===
* Id: 63B71D8
* User: Newslinger#top
* Date: 2018-10-16 12:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|864314259|SCI 864314259}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|864314261|MEDIA 864314261}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|864314265|POL 864314265}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|868949931|SCI 868949931}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|868949935|MEDIA 868949935}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|868949937|POL 868949937}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following should be the [[MOS:BEGIN|opening paragraph]] of the [[Sci-Hub]] article?

'''Option 1''' (from [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sci-Hub&oldid=864273518 revision 864273518]):
{{tq2|'''Sci-Hub''' is a website with over 70 million [[academic paper]]s and articles available for direct download.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web |title=Sci-Hub |accessdate=3 August 2018 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180803151437/https://sci-hub.tw |archivedate=2018-08-03 |df= }}</ref> It bypasses publisher [[paywall]]s by allowing access through educational institution proxies. Sci-Hub stores papers in its own [[Cache (computing)|cache]] to speed up future requests.}}

'''Option 2''' (from [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sci-Hub&oldid=864287916 revision 864287916]):
{{tq2|'''Sci-Hub''' is the world's largest source of pirated [[academic paper]]s and articles.<ref name="Bohannon_20160429">{{cite journal |author= John Bohannon |title= Who's downloading pirated papers? Everyone |journal= [[Science (journal)|Science]] |doi= 10.1126/science.aaf5664 |url= http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/04/whos-downloading-pirated-papers-everyone |date=28 April 2016 |volume=352 |number=6285 |pages= 508–512}}</ref>
 It bypasses publisher [[paywall]]s by illegally using educational institution proxies,<ref>{{cite journal| title=Sci-Hub: What Librarians Should Know and Do about Article Piracy |author=Matthew B. Hoy | journal=Medical Reference Services Quarterly |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages=73–78 | doi=10.1080/02763869.2017.1259918|pmid=28112638 |year=2017 }}</ref> after which it stores papers in its own [[Cache (computing)|cache]] to speed up future requests.}}

'''Option 3''' (current version):
{{tq2|'''Sci-Hub''' is a website which claims to have over 70 million [[academic paper]]s and articles available for direct download.<ref name=":8" />{{better source|date=October 2018}} It is stated to be the world's largest source of pirated [[academic paper]]s and articles.<ref name="Bohannon_20160429" /> It bypasses publisher [[paywall]]s by using educational institution proxies with credentials to which the site is not entitled,<ref>{{cite journal| title=Sci-Hub: What Librarians Should Know and Do about Article Piracy |author=Matthew B. Hoy | journal=Medical Reference Services Quarterly |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages=73–78 | doi=10.1080/02763869.2017.1259918|pmid=28112638 |year=2017 }}</ref> after which it stores papers in its own [[Cache (computing)|cache]] to speed up future requests.}}

As "sci-hub.tw" is on the [[MediaWiki talk:Spam-blacklist#sci-hub has a new TLD|Wikipedia spam blacklist]], I've removed the URL from the citation in Option 1. You can see the original citation in [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sci-Hub&oldid=864273518 revision 864273518].
{{tref}}

—&nbsp;'''''[[User:Newslinger|<span style="color:#536267;">Newslinger</span>]]'''&nbsp;<small>[[User talk:Newslinger#top|<span style="color:#708090;">talk</span>]]</small>'' 12:49, 16 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Tucker Carlson#rfc_7550D7C|Talk:Tucker Carlson]] expired 2018-11-15 13:01 ===
* Id: 7550D7C
* User: Snooganssnoogans
* Date: 2018-10-16 12:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|864314265|POL 864314265}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|868949937|POL 868949937}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following sentence be added to a paragraph on Carlson's white supremacist discourse:

* White supremacists, such as [[Richard B. Spencer]] and [[David Duke]], and the white nationalist website [[The Daily Stormer]] have lauded Carlson's show.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/tucker-carlson-changing-american-demographics-segment-slammed-twitter-2018-3?r=US&IR=T|title=People are calling Tucker Carlson out on Twitter for his segment criticizing 'changing demographics in America'|work=Business Insider|access-date=September 29, 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":102">Lenz, Lyz (September 5, 2018). [https://www.cjr.org/the_profile/tucker-carlson.php "The mystery of Tucker Carlson,"] ''Columbia Journalism Review.''</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/09/28/media/fox-news-laura-ingraham-tucker-carlson-white-nationalism/index.html|title=White anxiety finds a home at Fox News|last=Business|first=Tom Kludt and Brian Stelter, CNN|work=CNN|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/tucker-carlson-is-winning-over-white-supremacist-america-1.5486838|title=How Fox News' Rising Star Tucker Carlson Is Winning Over White Supremacist America|date=2017|work=Haaretz|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en}}</ref>

{{reflist-talk}}

Please indicate whether you '''support''' or '''oppose''' something similar to the above text, along with your reasoning. [[User:Snooganssnoogans|Snooganssnoogans]] ([[User talk:Snooganssnoogans|talk]]) 12:17, 16 October 2018 (UTC)}}

* Id: CEFA471

* Date: 2018-10-19 10:56:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|864773399|ECON 864773399}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|864773402|SCI 864773402}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|864773405|POL 864773405}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|869403960|ECON 869403960}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|869403965|SCI 869403965}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|869403968|POL 869403968}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
In a disease article, how can we include treatments such as those in the following list of examples:
#	treatment not available in the US, not FDA approved , 
#	treatment available on an expanded access / compassionate use only basis according to the FDA?
#	treatment approved for therapeutic use  by a foreign ruling authority of a government
#	treatment not proven effective (with a statement that it has not been proven effective)
This RfC is about building a consensus on a way to present such treatments in the present article. Wikipedians are invited to join in, including those from non-medical fields.
This RfC is the logical  follow up of the discussion that appears just before on [[Talk:Methicillin-resistant_Staphylococcus_aureus]]. 
[[User:Riffstilde|Riffstilde]] ([[User talk:Riffstilde|talk]]) 10:56, 19 October 2018 (UTC)}}

There is a discussion between two editors on whether or not this article's history section should contain any mention of what the 1st-century historian, [[Josephus]], wrote about a site in [[Judea]] called ''Gerasa'' (Hebrew: ''Jarash''), distinct from [[Jerash]] (''Gerasa'') in Transjordan, and whose inhabitants were involved in the war against the Roman army in Judea, in roughly ''anno'' 65 of our [[Common era]]. The article, Jarash, is thought by one editor to have possibly been connected to the reference made by Josephus, and wants to include a reference of the episode in the history section of Jarash..[[User:Davidbena|Davidbena]] ([[User talk:Davidbena|talk]]) 23:31, 17 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_A5A8647|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2018-11-19 05:01 ===
* Id: A5A8647
* User: Pkbwcgs
* Date: 2018-11-16 16:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|869134508|POLICY 869134508}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|869529011|POLICY 869529011}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
After what is turning out to be an unsuccessful proposal at [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#Proposal/RfC - Extend WP:U5 to the draftspace]], I have come up with something new. I reckon that we should allow proposed deletions in the draftspace. This will ensure that things like [[WP:NOTESSAY]], [[WP:NOTWEBHOST]] and [[WP:NOTHOWTO]] trash can be PRODed instead of having to go into [[WP:MfD]]. Also, [[WP:PROD]] has a seven-day wait most of the time before the page is deleted so it can mean that things can be deleted after seven days with proposed deletions in the draftspace without having to go to [[WP:MfD]] for basic things like [[WP:NOTESSAY]], [[WP:NOTWEBHOST]] and [[WP:NOTHOWTO]] which have no chance and obviously will get deleted. [[User:Pkbwcgs|Pkbwcgs]] ([[User talk:Pkbwcgs|talk]]) 16:23, 16 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Identifying reliable sources#rfc_58040BD|Wikipedia talk:Identifying reliable sources]] expired 2018-11-19 09:01 ===
* Id: 58040BD
* User: Newslinger#top
* Date: 2018-10-20 08:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|864904795|POLICY 864904795}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|869550649|POLICY 869550649}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following section be included in {{sectionlink|Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources|Questionable sources}}?
{{tq2|

''' Web content by non-staff contributors '''

{{Shortcut|WP:CONTRIBUTOR|WP:CONTRIBUTORS}}
On [[Online newspaper|news websites]], [[periodical]] websites (excluding [[academic journals]]), and [[blog]]s, [[web content]] authored by non-staff [[Freelancer|contributors]] is questionable if the contributors are subject to reduced editorial oversight, even if the web content is published in a source that is otherwise reliable. Compared to [[staff writer]]s, contributors generally have a lesser reputation for fact-checking and error correction. Reliable publications distinguish articles written by staff writers from ones written by contributors by indicating the author's job title in the [[byline]]. Less reputable sources only display the author's job title on their profile page or the website's [[Masthead (publishing)|masthead]].

Examples of sources that publish content from non-staff contributors include [[WP:RSP#Forbes.com contributors|Forbes.com]] and ''[[WP:RSP#HuffPost contributors|HuffPost]]''.

[[Opinion piece]]s in reliable sources have their [[#Statements of opinion|own guideline]], which applies instead of this one.
}}
—&nbsp;'''''[[User:Newslinger|<span style="color:#536267;">Newslinger</span>]]'''&nbsp;<small>[[User talk:Newslinger#top|<span style="color:#708090;">talk</span>]]</small>'' 08:03, 20 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Sérgio Moro#rfc_6CAE12D|Talk:Sérgio Moro]] expired 2018-11-20 18:01 ===
* Id: 6CAE12D
* User: Coltsfan
* Date: 2018-11-20 00:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|869660216|UNSORTED 869660216}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|869836187|UNSORTED 869836187}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== Not biased. '''

Part of the article contains critiques on Moro, but article itself is not biased as it contains no subjective matter, only well-sourced facts. For balancing, needs more content on so-called achievements instead of deleting sourced content. Critiques on article, on the other hand, are biased as they state sources aren't reliable when they're established media outlets serving as source for numerous articles in Wikipedia. We can't start judjing sources as unreliable based only on their political leanings.  

:ConJur is a [[WP:PARTISAN]] source. CartaCapital links are dead and together with CartaCampinas both are declared left-wing publication that doesn't meet [[WP:RS]] and [[WP:V]]. Rede Brasil Atual is a [[WP:QUESTIONABLE]] editoral.

:The controversy section ignores Moro's highly popular and praised merits and only focuses on leftist rhetoric. The Portuguese article don't even have those criticism.
::Sources present are major jornalistic ones, such as [[Folha de São Paulo]] and [[Universo Online]]. All other sources are also well accepted and are currently in use in other articles. And in the article in portuguese Wiki, actually, the "criticism section" is [[:pt:Sérgio Moro#Críticas|twice as big]]. So, this is neither here nor there. [[User:Coltsfan|Coltsfan]] ([[User talk:Coltsfan|talk]]) 00:59, 20 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Leo Tolstoy#rfc_2DCF714|Talk:Leo Tolstoy]] expired 2018-11-20 19:01 ===
* Id: 2DCF714
* User: AveTory
* Date: 2018-10-21 18:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|865102458|BIO 865102458}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|865102460|HIST 865102460}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|865102464|LANG 865102464}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|865102466|MEDIA 865102466}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|869843525|BIO 869843525}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|869843526|HIST 869843526}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|869843528|LANG 869843528}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|869843531|MEDIA 869843531}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should [[Leo Tolstoy]]'s pronunciation of his own name ("Lyov" per Lectures on Russian Literature by [[Vladimir Nabokov]]) be included in the article in the lead or as a footnote? It's a very uncommon transliteration of the Russian name Lev, especially in connection to Tolstoy who has been widely known by the names Lev and Leo in Russia and worldwide, with few sources referring to him as "Lyov" as I showed on the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Leo_Tolstoy#The_article_should_include_the_sourced_statement_that_Tolstoy_pronounced_his_first_name_as_%E2%80%98Lyov%E2%80%99 talk page]. The user who brought it up insists it should go in the lead even before the Lev name, while I agree to leave it as a footnote like in the [[:ru:Толстой, Лев Николаевич|Russian version of the article]], without additional changes to his birth/native name and further clarifications. [[User:AveTory|AveTory]] ([[User talk:AveTory|talk]]) 18:46, 21 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Health and appearance of Michael Jackson#rfc_B2C6344|Talk:Health and appearance of Michael Jackson]] expired 2018-11-21 19:01 ===
* Id: B2C6344
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2018-10-23 12:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|865359292|MEDIA 865359292}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|865359295|SOC 865359295}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|869997285|MEDIA 869997285}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|869997287|SOC 869997287}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is disagreement on whether [[:Category:American people with disabilities]], [[:Category:Artists with disabilities]], [[:Category:Disability media]] and [[:Category:Disability articles needing expert attention‏‎]] should be retained in this article. One view is that the categories should be retained because Jackson had [[vitiligo]]. The other view is that per [[WP:EGRS]], "which requires that categories about disability (and other personal features) only be applied when the subject has reliably and with some consistently been described as disabled and that the disability is in some way relevant to the person's notability," the categories don't belong. Also, [[:Category:Musicians with physical disabilities]] has been proposed as a replacement for the aforementioned categories. And, additionally, it has been noted that these categories are not in the [[Michael Jackson]] article, which is the main biography article. [[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 12:35, 23 October 2018 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Concerning this 9 year old sentence: 
:''The term 'POV-pushing' is primarily used in regard to the presentation of a particular point of view in an article and generally does not apply to talk page discussions.''

Should this sentence be removed and the text changed to explicitly apply to talk pages, or is the above line a reasonable explanation of the first line of [[WP:NPOV]] in that the NPOV policy (and its supplements) only apply to encyclopedic content and not talk pages?

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Schools#rfc_8941AC4|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Schools]] expired 2018-11-23 17:01 ===
* Id: 8941AC4
* User: Hammersoft
* Date: 2018-10-24 16:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|865554988|POL 865554988}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|865554991|SOC 865554991}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|870268978|POL 870268978}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|870268979|SOC 870268979}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been debate recently about which administrators should be included on school and school district articles. While [[WP:WPSCH/AG#WNTI]] indicates we should not be including anything other than the principal/head teacher, that is an essay as {{ping|Alansohn}} has noted. There was a discussion on this talk page on this subject above, but the respondents would have been only those interested in this project. I am therefore seeking wider input via this RfC. 

'''Question:''' Should school and school district articles include any administrators other than principal/head teacher/headmaster/superintendent even if we have one or more sources to support administrators below the top administrator?

'''Examples:''' '''(1)''' With only the principal; [[Dublin High School (California)]] and '''(2)''' With others below the principal; [[Bayonne High School]] (infobox and [[Bayonne_High_School#Administration]])

Thank you, --[[User:Hammersoft|Hammersoft]] ([[User talk:Hammersoft|talk]]) 16:40, 24 October 2018 (UTC)}}

* User: David Tornheim

(1) Should this sentence remain in the [[Brett Kavanaugh]] article:

:Between September 10 and 16, 2018, Kavanaugh had the highest opposition (42%) of any of the eleven Supreme Court nominees [[Gallup (company)|Gallup]] has polled about since Robert Bork in 1987.<ref name="dinan1">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/sep/23/brett-kavanaugh-support-slips-public-believes-accu/|title=Kavanaugh support slips as public believes accuser|last=Dinan|first=Stephen|date=September 23, 2018|newspaper=The Washington Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="jones1">{{cite news|url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/242300/opposition-kavanaugh-rising-accusation.aspx|title=Opposition to Kavanaugh Had Been Rising Before Accusation|last=Jones|first=Jeffery|date=September 18, 2018|agency=Gallup|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

:A [[YouGov]]/''[[The Economist]]'' poll on September 23–25 found 55% of Republicans thought he should be confirmed even if the allegations of sexual assault were true, compared to 28% of the whole sample and 13% of Democrats.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/sexual-assault-should-not-disqualify-kavanaugh-proven-majority-republicans-1141877|title=Majority of GOP in poll: Sexual assault shouldn’t disqualify Kavanaugh if proven|date=September 27, 2018|work=Newsweek|access-date=September 28, 2018|language=en}}</ref>

Please note that both sentences are already in the [[Brett Kavanaugh Supreme Court nomination]] article.  They are at the [[Brett_Kavanaugh_Supreme_Court_nomination#Public_reactions_and_polling|Public reactions and polling]] section.

{{reflist}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|870435180|BIO 870435180}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Hi, this image is awful and very poorly reflects the image of the subject. in violation of [[MOS:IMAGELEAD]] and [[wp:blp]] please see the awful photo here, [[Doria_Ragland#/media/File:Doria_Ragland.png]] it was claimed in the previous discussion that the photo is '''better than nothing''', is that the wikipedia policy way? [[User:Govindaharihari|Govindaharihari]] ([[User talk:Govindaharihari|talk]]) 19:52, 25 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Trypophobia#rfc_573378E|Talk:Trypophobia]] expired 2018-11-26 00:01 ===
* Id: 573378E
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2018-10-26 23:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|865909221|SCI 865909221}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|865909223|MEDIA 865909223}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|865909226|SOC 865909226}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|870617050|SCI 870617050}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|870617052|MEDIA 870617052}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|870617055|SOC 870617055}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been much debate about [[:File:Nelumbo Nucifera fruit - botanic garden Adelaide.jpg|this image]] (of a lotus seed pod) at the [[Trypophobia]] article. So far, the debate has produced [[Talk:Trypophobia/Archive 1#discussion|a 2013 RfC]], [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)/Archive 122#Images on phobia articles|a 2015 Village pump (policy) discussion]], a [[Talk:Trypophobia/Archive 2#RfC Should we include this image?|2015 RfC here at this talk page]], and now this one. The first RfC closed as no consensus to remove the image, the second discussion did not have an official close, but more editors leaned toward excluding the image (and other phobia images in phobia articles), and the final RfC closed as consensus for including the image. The discussions have concerned whether or not including the image is beneficial to readers, and whether or not it causes unnecessary harm to our readers. One view has been that the image is educational because demonstrating what induces trypophobia is not easy since a simple explanation of "a fear of holes" or "irregular patterns or clusters of small holes, or bumps" does not suffice. People with trypophobia can look at holes or irregular patterns and not have a reaction. Rather, the condition is about certain patterns, and in particular images that present high-contrast energy at low and midrange spatial frequencies. Lotus seed pod imagery is commonly noted as imagery that induces trypophobia and is used by researchers to test for trypophobia. Another view is that the image is irrelevant, decorative, or not needed, and that, even if it is educational, it causes unnecessary harm to our readers; this is seen, for example, [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Trypophobia&diff=825431354&oldid=825177525 here] and [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Trypophobia&diff=853832257&oldid=851901689 here]. [[WP:NOTCENSORED]] has been cited in past discussions. Some have felt that removing the image based on the possibility that it might harm readers, especially if the condition is not real or an actual phobia, is censoring. Others have stated that this is not a matter of WP:NOTCENSORED; it's a matter of whether we really need the image for the topic and whether we want to risk causing our readers harm. The imagery won't harm those without trypophobia, but it will harm those with it (they are the ones most likely to visit this article) and, with more research on the topic having been done since past discussions, researchers are are clear that it exists and does induce negative psychological or autonomic nervous system responses. 

As a compromise, editors have suggested collapsing the image (although collapsing it has been noted as something that would cause accessibility issues), or moving the image far down the page. '''So should we remove the image? Retain the image in the lead, but collapse it? Or move it lower?''' [[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 23:45, 26 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Tattoo medical issues#rfc_CAB750B|Talk:Tattoo medical issues]] expired 2018-11-28 22:01 ===
* Id: CAB750B
* User: Shibbolethink
* Date: 2018-11-28 16:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|871053557|SCI 871053557}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|871053560|SOC 871053560}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|871053561|STYLE 871053561}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|871094426|SCI 871094426}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|871094430|SOC 871094430}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|871094432|STYLE 871094432}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should this page be renamed from "Tattoo medical issues" to "'''Medical issues of tattooing'''" or "'''Health effects of tattoos'''"?

The name as it stands seems to be "off" to me. It's hard to explain, but I guess I would say it violates wiki convention and doesn't make much grammatical/style sense. In one aspect, it's ''quick and to the point'' but in another it seems somehow ''undignified'' and ''simplistic''. I would also say that the current title is not exactly NPOV, given that no substantial health effects have ever been discovered from sterile and safe tattooing practices in modern tattoo parlors. (This is also a problem the article itself has as a whole, with focus on esoteric and rare complications as if they are common. I'm interested in revamping the article to reflect that, and will be doing so over the next few weeks.) Perhaps "Health effects of tattoos" would be more neutral and aesthetically pleasing. But what does everyone else think? Please add your votes and discussion below in bold like so: 

*'''Health effects of tattoos''' - Commentary goes here. --[[User:Shibbolethink|<span style="color: black">Shibboleth</span><span style="color: maroon">ink</span>]] <sup>([[User talk:Shibbolethink|♔]]</sup> <sup>[[Special:Contributions/Shibbolethink|♕]])</sup> 16:12, 28 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Straight-through processing#rfc_6EF5EA5|Talk:Straight-through processing]] expired 2018-11-30 13:01 ===
* Id: 6EF5EA5
* User: Justiceforstp
* Date: 2018-10-31 12:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|866616488|ECON 866616488}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|866616490|SCI 866616490}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|871346300|ECON 871346300}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|871346301|SCI 871346301}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Although a request for citation has been present since May 2017, there have been no citations added to support the claims that Mr James Karat "invented" STP. STP is a well known concept and not an invention created by a single person. It is simply the automation of business processes. There is no mention of what role Mr Karat played in the automation of the process - it appears he was working on an automation project anyway, so is it actually the case that he was the "jobber" and not a business process architect, system architect, system developer or any person who could have claim to "inventing" a concept. It appears that the entries have been made by Mr Karat himself and not someone independent. In fact in April 2016 the Edit History shows [[user:Graemeaustin|Graeme Austin]] commenting "Origination of phrase is in fact in dispute. James Karat may have been the first but I was deeply involved in STP in the early 90s in London and he is not known to me."

Should references to Mr Karat be removed?

[[User:Justiceforstp|Justiceforstp]] ([[User talk:Justiceforstp|talk]]) 12:24, 31 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Instrumentalism#rfc_E95D0E6|Talk:Instrumentalism]] expired 2018-11-30 15:01 ===
* Id: E95D0E6
* User: TBR-qed
* Date: 2018-10-31 14:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|866631784|SCI 866631784}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|868546436|RELI 868546436}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|871359893|SCI 871359893}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|871359895|RELI 871359895}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Has the author violated WP protocols?
I have been accused of violating WP protocols in this and other articles.  I replaced an accurate article, violating WP: NPOV, NOR, SYN:NOR, UNDUE, OWN.  I welcome the opportunity to show why these charges are mistaken.  All of the elements of my case appear in the “Instrumentalism” lede, which now replaces my article in order to restore the status quo anti which I replaced in 2014.

The present lede defines instrumentalism as an “interpretation” or “theory” that “scientific theory is merely a tool” of prediction that says nothing about unobservable reality.  It claims this proposition was introduced by Duhem in 1906, and is the prevailing theory-of-theory in physics today.  It then states that instrumentalism is a form of anti-realism—the “demise” of which is claimed in the historical discussion that follows.  Thus INSTRUMENTALISM IS BOTH ALIVE AND DEAD—a paradox stated as a fact.  This characterization of instrumentalism in the original and present article is inaccurate, which explains my decision to replace.[[User:TBR-qed|TBR-qed]] ([[User talk:TBR-qed|talk]]) 14:42, 31 October 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums#rfc_336AAC3|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums]] expired 2018-12-01 03:01 ===
* Id: 336AAC3
* User: Levivich
* Date: 2018-11-30 00:00:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|871442517|POL 871442517}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
When should an article state that a candidate has won an election?
# When the election is ''certified'' by election authorities
# When the election is ''conceded'' by the other candidates? (All other candidates? The second-place candidate?)
# When the election is ''called'' by reliable sources? (All sources? Most sources? A particular source?)
# When I say it is
# Some combination of the above (whichever happens first)
# None of the above; something else entirely
[[User:Levivich|Levivich]] ([[User talk:Levivich|talk]]) 00:00, 30 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Selfref#rfc_FF88BED|Template talk:Selfref]] expired 2018-12-03 14:01 ===
* Id: FF88BED
* User: Hddty.
* Date: 2018-11-03 13:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|867076740|TECH 867076740}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|868453782|POLICY 868453782}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|871795618|TECH 871795618}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we make this template hidden in the article mainspace with a code to those who doesn't logged in, especially readers? The articles that linked using this template are mostly only in the interest of the editors and often distract the readers who come here only to read (example: [[Fair use]], [[Internet troll]], [[International Phonetic Alphabet]]). We already put links to the project page at the left bar and from the Main Page. Some would probably argue that this hatnote would attract new editors, however that's not our purpose, our purpose is to create an encyclopedia. Per [[Wikipedia:Hatnote]]: "Their purpose is to help readers locate a different article if the one they are at is not the one they're looking for", most readers not even intended to look for the project namespace in the first place. This discussion is almost similar to [[WP:CNR]]. [[User:Hddty.|Hddty.]] ([[User talk:Hddty.|talk]]) 13:16, 3 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of years in Bulgaria#rfc_305E00B|Talk:List of years in Bulgaria]] expired 2018-12-04 00:02 ===
* Id: 305E00B
* User: Cunard
* Date: 2018-11-03 23:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

=== [[Talk:Social Liberal Party (Brazil)#rfc_2ECC7F1|Talk:Social Liberal Party (Brazil)]] expired 2018-12-05 05:01 ===
* Id: 2ECC7F1
* User: Berzerker king
* Date: 2018-11-08 23:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|867943870|POL 867943870}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|872752274|POL 872752274}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The following links were added to show that the social liberal party's categorization as far right is disputed.

https://www.heritage.org/americas/commentary/will-jair-bolsonaro-make-brazil-great-again

https://www.foxnews.com/world/fascist-populist-debate-over-describing-brazils-bolsonaro

https://www.forbes.com/sites/kenrapoza/2018/10/08/how-bolsonaro-becomes-brazils-next-president/#7f908bc457e5

The links mentioned above and the "disputed" tag was removed from the article. They were removed with comments that the article does not discuss the party itself. While at the same time, the following citations were allowed to remain, which also do not discuss the party as such, but propose the opposite point of view than the ones that were being presented in the articles that were removed. The effect of removing the links mentioned above while allowing the links given below to remain, was that only a single point of view was allowed to express as a commentary on the political party while the opposing point of views were not allowed to be present.

https://www.newstatesman.com/world/2018/10/why-brazil-s-far-right-challenger-jair-bolsonaro-has-already-won

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/07/brazil-presidential-election-far-right-populist-jair-bolsonaro

https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-44919769

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/28/world/americas/jair-bolsonaro-brazil-election.html

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-election-congress-analysis/bolsonaro-transforms-tiny-brazil-party-into-congressional-powerhouse-idUSKCN1MI07Q

https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2018/10/brazil-election-democracy-jair-bolsonaro-lula-haddad/572470/

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-election/brazils-far-right-bolsonaro-no-coalition-politics-in-cabinet-picks-idUSKCN1MJ27U

https://www.infomoney.com.br/mercados/politica/noticia/7324428/com-bolsonaro-extrema-direita-embarca-forte-para-vencer-nesta-eleicao

https://brasil.elpais.com/brasil/2018/08/05/politica/1533482571_722395.html

I wish to propose that either the other citations which do not discuss the party also be removed on the same grounds that they do not discuss the party as such, or that the 3 links I mentioned above also be added along with a "disputed" tag to show that the "Far-right" designation of the party is disputed. --[[User:Berzerker king|Berzerker king]] ([[User talk:Berzerker king|talk]]) 23:24, 8 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Social Liberal Party (Brazil)#rfc_91299FD|Talk:Social Liberal Party (Brazil)]] expired 2018-12-05 05:01 ===
* Id: 91299FD
* User: Berzerker king
* Date: 2018-11-05 04:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|867943872|POLICY 867943872}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|872104600|POLICY 872104600}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Wikipedia policy on neutral point of view clearly states that if an opnion is stated in a news then it must be clarified in the encyclopedia entry that it is opinion of someone and not a fact

"Usually, articles will contain information about the significant opinions that have been expressed about their subjects. However, these opinions should not be stated in Wikipedia's voice"

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view

The citations given are from websites with questionable integrity like infomoney.br, of whose charter and aims we know nothing about. Also the citations do not explain at all why the labelling of "far-right" has been done, it just uses it casually.

It is highly improper to use newspaper articles in this manner. News can be used as citation to say "event x occurred", but not as a conclusive evidence to say "x is a bad person" or "x is a far right" or "x is a far left". I disagree with this kind of biased approach and I request for comments.

[[User:Berzerker king|Berzerker king]] ([[User talk:Berzerker king|talk]]) 04:59, 5 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_30DAB4C|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2018-12-05 13:01 ===
* Id: 30DAB4C
* User: Pkbwcgs
* Date: 2018-11-12 17:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|868513232|POLICY 868513232}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|873355291|POLICY 873355291}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am going to propose that [[WP:U5]] gets extended to the draftspace. This is because the draftspace is being abused in a way that there are so many drafts being found daily which are basically [[WP:NOTWEBHOST]]. It is mainly point 5 of [[WP:NOTWEBHOST]] which I am seeing in loads of drafts. Rule 5 of [[WP:NOTWEBHOST]] is "Content for projects unrelated to Wikipedia. Do not store material unrelated to Wikipedia, including in userspace." and I am seeing that new users are using the draftspace in a way so that [[WP:U5]] can be escaped because [[WP:U5]] does not apply to the draftspace at the moment. If this is implemented, there will be less drafts coming to [[WP:MfD]] daily that could actually do with being speedily deleted per [[WP:U5]]. 

My new proposed wording for [[WP:U5]] is:

Pages in userspace or draftspace consisting of [[WP:NOTWEBHOST|writings, information, discussions, and/or activities not closely related to Wikipedia's goals]], where the owner has made few or no edits outside of [[Wikipedia:User pages|user pages]] and [[Wikipedia:Drafts|drafts]], with the exception of plausible drafts and pages adhering to [[Wikipedia:User pages#What may I have in my user pages?]].

[[User:Pkbwcgs|Pkbwcgs]] ([[User talk:Pkbwcgs|talk]]) 17:21, 12 November 2018 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_B4E556A|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2018-12-05 13:01 ===
* Id: B4E556A
* User: Thryduulf
* Date: 2018-11-05 12:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|868722442|POLICY 868722442}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|872147793|POLICY 872147793}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[WP:CSD#G6|Criterion G6]] is overloaded with many different things all lumped together as "uncontroversial maintenance" and is the most frequently abused of all criteria. It would never be approved if proposed as is today. The best way to solve this, in my opinion, is to unbundle the various different reasons into separate criteria that are individually objective. I'm not proposing to do this all at once, but to work on it step-by-step so that objections to one aspect don't derail the whole thing.

One aspect of G6 stands out as being a particularly poor fit with the rest: "Deleting redirects in the "File:" namespace with the same name as a file or redirect at Commons, provided the redirect on Wikipedia has no file links (unless the links are obviously intended for the file or redirect at Commons)." Accordingly I propose to move this criterion, without any changes, from G6 to a new R4 for these reasons:
*It deals only with redirects, and is thus where someone will look for it
*The general footer to the R criteria (don't speedy delete redirects with significant history, use RfD for redirects that don't meet the criteria) apply to these redirects equally with others
*It contains requirements that are significantly different to other things deleted using G6
*This isn't really "maintenance" in the same sense as other aspects of G6 (e.g. pages created in error/in the wrong place, etc)
*Deletion summaries will become more useful.
This does not change what can be speedy deleted, just under which criterion is gets speedy deleted. [[User:Thryduulf|Thryduulf]] ([[User talk:Thryduulf|talk]]) 12:43, 5 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2.0 (film)#rfc_5DFC406|Talk:2.0 (film)]] expired 2018-12-06 18:01 ===
* Id: 5DFC406
* User: Cyphoidbomb
* Date: 2018-11-06 17:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|867587339|MEDIA 867587339}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|872329487|MEDIA 872329487}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Background: There are no official reporting agencies for budget or gross figures in Indian cinema. News outlets must rely on their proprietary methods for estimating these values, and sometimes outlets' values conflict.

Some reliable sources, including Times of India[https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/photo-features/rajinikanth-and-akshay-kumars-2-0-times-when-the-film-made-headlines/rs-543-crore-spent-on-vfx-of-the-akshay-kumar-and-rajinikanth-starrer-2-0/photostory/65770317.cms] have estimated this film's budget at {{INR|link=yes}}543 [[crore]] ({{INR|link=yes}}5.43 billion). Another source generally considered reliable, Bollywood Hungama, has cast doubts on the high figures being reported, presenting a budget estimate of {{INR|link=yes}}400 crore ({{INR|link=yes}}4 billion).[https://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/bollywood/revealed-real-budget-rajinikanth-akshay-kumar-starrer-2-0/]

Should we:
* Present the budget as {{INR}}543 crore?
* Present the budget as a range between {{INR}}400–543 crore?
Thanks, [[User:Cyphoidbomb|Cyphoidbomb]] ([[User talk:Cyphoidbomb|talk]]) 17:32, 6 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Tucker Carlson#rfc_1CAB85D|Talk:Tucker Carlson]] expired 2018-12-07 20:01 ===
* Id: 1CAB85D
* User: Proustfala
* Date: 2018-12-06 18:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|872340909|BIO 872340909}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|872340912|MEDIA 872340912}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|872552345|BIO 872552345}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|872552348|MEDIA 872552348}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi all, I noticed Siri Knowledge incorrectly listed TC as a Republican, went to edit on Wikipedia (where I think Siri Knowledge is sourced from) and actually no party was listed at all. Another user who seems to have an axe to grind is deleting this factual information because TC doesn't meet their standards of what they personally think a Democrat is. Not sure how to proceed with this, as when I have reverted unwarranted deletions like this in the past, I usually end up with warnings for 'edit warring' and whatnot. Could anyone advise as to how to proceed so that factual information can be reflected in this article? 

Just to clarify, TC is a Democrat. A user is arguing that it's 'extremely disingenuous'/'misleading' to then state in his bio that he is Democrat. I'm not sure I understand the argument - it seems counter-rational. But maybe someone can enlighten. [[User:Proustfala|Proustfala]] ([[User talk:Proustfala|talk]]) 18:34, 6 December 2018 (UTC)}}

I would like to propose that we slightly change the formatting of this table in order to improve the [[readability]] of the info. Towards the beginning and end of the seasons this is less of an issue but during the majority of the season I find myself having to count the number of cells in order to see what result was for each team. I would therefore like to propose that we adjust the table slightly to the format I have prepared here: 11:50, 9 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Nikola Tesla/Nationality and ethnicity#rfc_F5C2C08|Talk:Nikola Tesla/Nationality and ethnicity]] expired 2018-12-12 01:01 ===
* Id: F5C2C08
* User: Bilseric
* Date: 2018-12-08 21:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|872739053|HIST 872739053}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|873247954|HIST 873247954}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'm inviting you to participate in the resolution of one of the most long term discussions on Wikipedia. 

Normally, an RfC wouldn't be needed for such a simple edit, but for anyone who's familiar with this article, it's known how hard this topic is. The lack of sources led to more than a decade of pointless discussions. 

The purpose of this RfC is not to change the current consensus or the article text, but to put a further context to the current consensus. After several years since the current consensus was established, readers were constantly confused by the article text, which led to numerous change requests. Since then, one editor made a good research and found a source which settles the whole debate. 

This source gives the exact definition of Tesla's birthplace. It is backed up by a primary source, thus making it the most strongest source on the matter.

The source gives this definition of Tesla's birthplace:

"After many pleas from Jelecic, in 1850 the King's proclamation, which was signed by all 8 Austrian ministers, was finally announced...For Military Frontier, the King decided that it will remain within its present territory. However, it will with, Croatia and Slavonia, constitute a single land with disaggregated provincial and military administration, and representation." , page 157. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.org/details/najnovijedobahrv00horv|title=Najnovije doba hrvatske povjesti|first=Rudolf|last=Horvat|date=8 December 2018|publisher=U Zagrebu Matica hrvatska|accessdate=8 December 2018|via=Internet Archive}}</ref>

There are two parts of this RfC. 

1.Rfc suggestion.
The purposed change is to add the mentioned source as a reference to this sentence:
Nikola Tesla was born an ethnic Serb in the village Smiljan, Lika county, in the Austrian Empire (present day Croatia), on 10 July [O.S. 28 June] 1856.[12][13]
{{reflist-talk}}

2.RfC question

Was Nikola Tesla born in a single Austrian land composed of Military Frontier, Croatia and Slavonia per provided source.  

Pinging some of the users who participated in the previous discussion: {{reply to|Srich32977|Martinevans123|Director|Bermicourt|Joy|Peacemaker67|Fountains of Bryn Mawr|Binksternet|Tom Hulse|Epicgenius|Atlantictire|Surtsicna|Enric Naval}} [[User:Bilseric|Bilseric]] ([[User talk:Bilseric|talk]]) 21:31, 8 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Ireland#rfc_6C177FD|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Ireland]] expired 2018-12-13 14:01 ===
* Id: 6C177FD
* Date: 2018-11-13 13:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|868635321|STYLE 868635321}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|873499399|STYLE 873499399}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'm a bit irritated by the inconsistency in how Northern Irish people are categorized on Wikipedia. Looking at [[:Category:DJs by nationality]], all of the DJs by nationality are categorized by the adjective form (e.g. "American DJs", "Russian DJs", "British DJs", even "[[:Category:Welsh DJs|Welsh DJs]]" and "[[:Category:Scottish DJs|Scottish DJs]]") '''but not Northern Irish DJs''' who are categorized as "[[:Category:DJs from Northern Ireland|DJs from Northern Ireland‎]]". I don't like this at all! I once started a CfD to change the DJs category but it was opposed on the basis that all the other Northern Irish people categories use the "xxx from Northern Ireland" form. So I'm proposing to change it on a wider scale, changing all category instances of "xxx from Northern Ireland" to "Northern Irish xxx" for consistency with the other similar categories of different countries. <u style="font:1.1em/1em Arial Black">[[User:Flooded with them hundreds|<u style="color:#7f2ed1">Flooded </u>]]<u style="color:#bfa6d8"><small>with them </small></u>[[User_talk:Flooded with them hundreds|<u style="color:#7f2ed1">'''hundreds'''</u>]]</u> 13:47, 13 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Baraboo High School#rfc_A8AA0E9|Talk:Baraboo High School]] expired 2018-12-14 06:01 ===
* Id: A8AA0E9
* User: John from Idegon
* Date: 2018-11-14 05:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|868818545|ECON 868818545}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|868818548|SOC 868818548}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|873645140|ECON 873645140}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|873645142|SOC 873645142}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As this discussion is rapidly spinning out of control (witness multiple sections being opened on the same topic and attempts to centralize the discussion being reverted), it appears a more formal (and widely publicized) solution is in order.

The question is: 

'''What if anything should we include at this time on the "Nazi salute controversy"?'''

It's also fairly clear we have four choices:
#Some variation (subject to discussion on the finer points) of what existed [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Baraboo_High_School&diff=prev&oldid=868681256 here].
#Nothing.
#Nothing for now, revisiting in say three months so we can accurately gauge the enduring nature of this information.
#A brief discussion of the school itself's role in this.

Please indicate your preferences in order from the one that most suits your position to the least suitable, along with your arguments.

Thanks. [[User:John from Idegon|John from Idegon]] ([[User talk:John from Idegon|talk]]) 05:04, 14 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Wade–Giles#rfc_C0D2B88|Talk:Wade–Giles]] expired 2018-12-14 14:01 ===
* Id: C0D2B88
* User: FineStructure137
* Date: 2018-11-14 14:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|868802911|HIST 868802911}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|868802923|STYLE 868802923}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|873689929|HIST 873689929}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|873689939|STYLE 873689939}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Should tone marks be used in Wade-Giles transliterations? Is it ''Wei<sup>1</sup> Chai<sup>2</sup> Shih<sup>4</sup> P&#x2bb;in<sup>1</sup>-yin<sup>1</sup>'' or ''Wei Chai Shih Pʻin-yin''?

'''TLDR''': You’d be hard pressed to find anyone other than Wikipedia who transliterates Chinese with Wade-Giles tone marks. I searched for ''Mao² Tsê²-tung¹'' on Gbooks and went away empty handed.

Until the early 1980s, Wade-Giles was that standard way to transliterate Chinese characters. It was popularized by ''[http://ebook.lib.hku.hk/CADAL/B33646119/ A Chinese-English Dictionary]''  (1912) by [[Herbert Giles]]. The entry titles in Giles’ dictionary are all-caps and without tone marks: “HUANG.” The idea that the system includes tones marks does not come from the dictionary itself, but rather from usage by Giles in the preface and supplementary tables of his dictionary.

The name "Wade-Giles system" is intended to suggest "Wade's system as implemented in Giles dictionary." But in fact the system is usually understood to encompass implementations by ''[[Mathews' Chinese-English Dictionary|Mathew's Dictionary]]'' (1943) and others. It is not the property of Herbert Giles. ''[https://www.britannica.com/topic/Wade-Giles-romanization#accordion-article-history Encyclopedia Britannica]''`s article on the system includes an extensive list of examples, none of them with tone marks. The multivolume reference work ''[[Cambridge History of China]]'' is one of the few places where the contemporary reader might encounter Wade-Giles in the wild, so to speak. The CHC implementation does not include tone marks. [[User:FineStructure137|FineStructure137]] ([[User talk:FineStructure137|talk]]) 14:01, 14 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Teahouse#rfc_A9A2E62|Wikipedia talk:Teahouse]] expired 2018-12-15 22:01 ===
* Id: A9A2E62
* User: Dreamy Jazz
* Date: 2018-12-04 15:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|872196145|TECH 872196145}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|873909637|TECH 873909637}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Would anyone object to the automatic substitution of [[Wikipedia:Teahouse/AfC Invitation]] and [[Wikipedia:Teahouse/Invitation]]. On both invitation templates, they already say that the invitation should be substituted. I have [[WP:BOLD|boldly]] added automatic substitution category for the AfC Invitation template, as substitution is already happening through the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject_Articles_for_creation/Helper_script|AfC Helper Script]]. However, for the normal invitation, this is not happening (in at least the Teahouse Helper Script). Because the transclusion count is [https://tools.wmflabs.org/templatecount/index.php?lang=en&namespace=4&name=Teahouse%2FInvitation#bottom ~50,000], {{u|AnomieBOT}} won't substitute this template until it is added to the [[User:AnomieBOT/TemplateSubster force|force page]]. A consensus is needed for this. Please indicate your '''support''' or '''oppose'''. [[User:Dreamy Jazz|Dreamy <i style="color:#d01e1e">'''Jazz'''</i>]] 🎷 <sup>''[[User talk:Dreamy Jazz|talk to me]]'' &#124; ''[[Special:Contributions/Dreamy Jazz|my contributions]]''</sup> 15:14, 4 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_6066D4F|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2018-12-17 19:01 ===
* Id: 6066D4F
* User: Ivanvector
* Date: 2018-11-22 17:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|870156008|POLICY 870156008}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|874946795|POLICY 874946795}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Yeah, I know, [[WP:PERENNIAL]]. But after yet another compromised inactive admin account ran amok over the project today, I feel like this should be revisited. The account in question did not have a logged action in over 2 years, and had made only 5 edits in 2017 and one in 2018. The policy [[Special:Permalink/866740594#Procedural removal for inactive administrators|as currently worded]] reads:

{{quotebox|Administrators who have made neither edits nor administrative actions for at least 12 months may be desysopped.<ref>[[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)/suspend sysop rights of inactive admins]], June 2011</ref> Subject to the [[#Lengthy inactivity|lengthy inactivity]] consideration below, this desysopping is not to be considered permanent, or a reflection on the user's use of, or rights to, the admin tools. The admin must be contacted on their user talk page and via e-mail (if possible) one month before the request for desysopping and again several days before the desysopping goes into effect. Desysopping on inactivity grounds should be handled by English Wikipedia [[Wikipedia:Bureaucrats|bureaucrats]]. The summary in the user rights log should make it clear that the desysopping is purely procedural.}}

I propose modifying this to:

{{quotebox|Administrators who have made no logged administrative actions for at least 12 months may be desysopped.<ref>[[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)/suspend sysop rights of inactive admins]], June 2011</ref> Subject to the [[#Lengthy inactivity|lengthy inactivity]] consideration below, this desysopping is not to be considered permanent, or a reflection on the user's use of, or rights to, the admin tools. Desysopping on inactivity grounds should be handled by English Wikipedia [[Wikipedia:Bureaucrats|bureaucrats]]. The summary in the user rights log should make it clear that the desysopping is purely procedural.}}

{{reflist-talk}}

The change removes the notification requirement, and the "edits" criterion. The effect is that admin accounts which don't use admin tools for 12 months will simply have the bit silently removed as a matter of security. We won't tell them we're about to do it, and then they won't log in and make one nonsense edit to hang on to the bit. Removal will just happen when they've been away long enough, and if they come back some time later and want to go back to adminning they just ask at BN and go through the 24-hour hold like anyone else whose bit has been voluntarily removed. In fact admins should be ''actively discouraged'' from "holding on to the bit" in this manner, but let's at least do this. [[User:Ivanvector|Ivanvector]] (<sup>[[User talk:Ivanvector|Talk]]</sup>/<sub>[[Special:Contributions/Ivanvector|Edits]]</sub>) 17:51, 22 November 2018 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Matthew Whitaker (attorney)#rfc_A2856AC|Talk:Matthew Whitaker (attorney)]] expired 2018-12-17 23:01 ===

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the the bolded content below be trimmed and the sourcing changed from ''[[The Washington Times]]'' to [[WGBH]] (Boston [[NPR]]/[[PBS]] affiliate) as follows ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Matthew_Whitaker_(attorney)&diff=872023883&oldid=871949016 diff]):

*From:
:Soon after Whitaker's appointment as Acting Attorney General, a "broad and growing array" of legal experts expressed concern.<ref name="vladek">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/09/opinion/trump-attorney-general-constitutional.html|title=Whitaker May Be a Bad Choice, but He’s a Legal One|last1=Vladeck|first1=Stephen I.|date=November 9, 2018|work=The New York Times|accessdate=November 9, 2018}}</ref> [[New York University]] law professor [[Ryan Goodman]] and [[Walter Shaub]], former director of the [[U.S. Office of Government Ethics]], argued for Whitaker to recuse himself from supervising the investigation, citing potential conflicts of interest such as his previous criticism of the Special Counsel investigation and his ties to [[Sam Clovis]] who is a witness in the investigation.<ref name="auto1"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Breuninger |first1=Kevin |title=Acting Attorney General Whitaker's views on Mueller probe prompt calls for his recusal |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/08/acting-ags-views-on-mueller-probe-prompt-warnings-from-experts.html |accessdate=November 9, 2018 |work=CNBC |date=November 8, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Gibson |first1=Ginger |title=Whitaker’s friendship with Trump aide reignites recusal debate |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-whitaker/whitakers-friendship-with-trump-aide-reignites-recusal-debate-idUSKCN1ND2SN |accessdate=November 9, 2018 |publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=November 9, 2018}}</ref> NYU law professor [[Stephen Gillers]] said Whitaker "has no such legal or ethical obligation to step aside" but agrees that "Whitaker should be recused. His repeated expression of hostility to the Mueller investigation makes it impossible for the public to have confidence in his ability to exercise the necessary prosecutorial judgment in supervising Mueller".<ref>Naham, Matt. [https://lawandcrime.com/legal-analysis/legal-expert-there-is-no-legal-ethics-issue-here-that-would-force-matthew-whitaker-to-recuse-himself/ Legal Expert: There Is ‘No Legal Ethics Issue Here’ That Would Force Matthew Whitaker to Recuse Himself], Law & Crime, November 7, 2018.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.justsecurity.org/61395/top-legal-ethics-professional-responsibility-expert-writes-whitaker-recuse/|title=Top Legal Ethics Expert (Stephen Gillers) Writes: Whitaker Should Be Recused |date=November 8, 2018|work=Just Security|access-date=November 10, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> According to people close to Whitaker, he does not have any plans to recuse.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Barrett |first1=Devlin |last2=Zapotosky |first2=Matt |last3=Dawsey |first3=Josh |title=Acting attorney general Whitaker has no intention of recusing himself from Russia probe, associates say |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trumps-acting-attorney-general-matt-whitaker-has-no-intention-of-recusing-from-russia-probe-associates-say/2018/11/08/a5bc8d90-e370-11e8-ab2c-b31dcd53ca6b_story.html?noredirect=on |accessdate=November 9, 2018 |work=Washington Post |date=November 8, 2018 |language=en}}</ref> '''Asked if Whitaker might be able to derail the investigation into alleged collusion between Donald Trump and his 2016 presidential campaign, and the Russian government, former [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] chief [[James Comey]] dismissed such concerns, venturing that Whitaker lacked sufficient influence in Washington to accomplish such a goal. "He may not be the sharpest knife in our drawer, but he can see his future and knows that if he acted in an extralegal way, he would go down in history for the wrong reasons and I’m sure he doesn’t want that," Comey remarked.<ref>[https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/nov/27/james-comey-says-matthew-whitaker-is-not-the-sharp/ James Comey dismisses Acting AG Matthew Whitaker as 'not the sharpest knife'], ''[[Washington Times]]'', Gabriella Munoz, November 20, 2018. Retrieved December 1, 2018.</ref>'''

*To:
:Soon after Whitaker's appointment as Acting Attorney General, a "broad and growing array" of legal experts expressed concern.<ref name="vladek">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/09/opinion/trump-attorney-general-constitutional.html|title=Whitaker May Be a Bad Choice, but He’s a Legal One|last1=Vladeck|first1=Stephen I.|date=November 9, 2018|work=The New York Times|accessdate=November 9, 2018}}</ref> [[New York University]] law professor [[Ryan Goodman]] and [[Walter Shaub]], former director of the [[U.S. Office of Government Ethics]], argued for Whitaker to recuse himself from supervising the investigation, citing potential conflicts of interest such as his previous criticism of the Special Counsel investigation and his ties to [[Sam Clovis]] who is a witness in the investigation.<ref name="auto1"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Breuninger |first1=Kevin |title=Acting Attorney General Whitaker's views on Mueller probe prompt calls for his recusal |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/08/acting-ags-views-on-mueller-probe-prompt-warnings-from-experts.html |accessdate=November 9, 2018 |work=CNBC |date=November 8, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Gibson |first1=Ginger |title=Whitaker’s friendship with Trump aide reignites recusal debate |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-whitaker/whitakers-friendship-with-trump-aide-reignites-recusal-debate-idUSKCN1ND2SN |accessdate=November 9, 2018 |publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=November 9, 2018}}</ref> NYU law professor [[Stephen Gillers]] said Whitaker "has no such legal or ethical obligation to step aside" but agrees that "Whitaker should be recused. His repeated expression of hostility to the Mueller investigation makes it impossible for the public to have confidence in his ability to exercise the necessary prosecutorial judgment in supervising Mueller".<ref>Naham, Matt. [https://lawandcrime.com/legal-analysis/legal-expert-there-is-no-legal-ethics-issue-here-that-would-force-matthew-whitaker-to-recuse-himself/ Legal Expert: There Is ‘No Legal Ethics Issue Here’ That Would Force Matthew Whitaker to Recuse Himself], Law & Crime, November 7, 2018.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.justsecurity.org/61395/top-legal-ethics-professional-responsibility-expert-writes-whitaker-recuse/|title=Top Legal Ethics Expert (Stephen Gillers) Writes: Whitaker Should Be Recused |date=November 8, 2018|work=Just Security|access-date=November 10, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> According to people close to Whitaker, he does not have any plans to recuse.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Barrett |first1=Devlin |last2=Zapotosky |first2=Matt |last3=Dawsey |first3=Josh |title=Acting attorney general Whitaker has no intention of recusing himself from Russia probe, associates say |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trumps-acting-attorney-general-matt-whitaker-has-no-intention-of-recusing-from-russia-probe-associates-say/2018/11/08/a5bc8d90-e370-11e8-ab2c-b31dcd53ca6b_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.d0530d4ab1cc |accessdate=November 9, 2018 |work=Washington Post |date=November 8, 2018 |language=en}}</ref> '''Former [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] director [[James Comey]] said he thought it was unlikely Whitaker would be able to derail the Mueller investigation and that if Whitaker did so, "he would go down in history for the wrong reasons and I’m sure he doesn’t want that."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wgbh.org/news/national-news/2018/11/26/i-always-respect-subpoenas-comey-says-his-legal-team-is-looking-at-his-options?utm_source=TWITTER&utm_medium=social&utm_term=20181127&utm_content=1929039737&utm_campaign=WGBH+News|title=‘I Always Respect Subpoenas’: Comey Says His Legal Team Is Looking At His Options|publisher=[[WGBH]]|date=November 26, 2018|author=WGBH News}}</ref>'''

=== [[Talk:Stakhanov, Ukraine#rfc_1C30B3C|Talk:Stakhanov, Ukraine]] expired 2018-12-19 00:02 ===
* Id: 1C30B3C
* User: Doremo
* Date: 2018-12-18 11:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|874305386|HIST 874305386}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|874305389|POL 874305389}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|874394505|HIST 874394505}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|874394507|POL 874394507}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should this article, "Stakhanov, Ukraine" (the name used from 1978 to 2016), be moved to "Kadiyivka" (the name restored on May 12, 2016)? — [[User:Doremo|Doremo]] ([[User talk:Doremo|talk]]) 11:35, 18 December 2018 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 

Should mention of the ''Federation Generation'' terminology and the references for this terminology be deleted from this article? This includes removing "Federation Generation" from the sentence in the lead which lists other names for the demographic cohort and also deleting this paragraph from the body of the article:

{{tq|"McCrindle Research expanded on Howe's work and uses the term ''Federation Generation'' to describe [[Australians|Australian]] members of this cohort, born between 1901–1924, "a time of peace when Australia finally secured nationhood" who came of age during The [[Great Depression]] and WWII and experienced post-war prosperity in midlife."<ref>[http://mccrindle.com.au/resources/whitepapers/McCrindle-Research_ABC-01_Generations-Defined_Mark-McCrindle.pdf Generations Defined]. Mark McCrindle {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616232732/http://mccrindle.com.au/resources/whitepapers/McCrindle-Research_ABC-01_Generations-Defined_Mark-McCrindle.pdf |date=2016-06-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=McCrindle|first1=Mark|title=The ABC of XYZ Understanding the Global Generations|url=http://www.saspa.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/The-ABC-of-XYZ_Chapter-1.pdf|accessdate=25 May 2018|publisher=McCrindle Research}}</ref>}} 15:20, 19 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Articles for deletion#rfc_ABCF40B|Wikipedia talk:Articles for deletion]] expired 2018-12-23 15:01 ===
* Id: ABCF40B
* User: Lojbanist
* Date: 2018-12-23 00:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|874993227|PROP 874993227}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|875066973|PROP 875066973}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Why not rename this to "Articles for Discussion", and then fold [[Wikipedia:Requested moves]], all of the {{tl|Merge}} stuff, all of the {{tl|Split}} stuff, and possibly [[WP:DRAFTIFY]] into one AFD process? I'm sure that there are one or two other process that could easily fit under an "articles for discussion" umbrella, as well. De-emphasizing deletion as the primary mechanism, even if it is only a "psychological" de-emphasis, certainly couldn't hurt anything though. Most importantly however, simplifying and centralizing 4-5 different processes into a single discussion forum could only help all of us as editors, I would think. [[User:Lojbanist|'''Kamafa Delgato''']] <sub>([[User:Lojbanist|Lojbanist]])</sub><sup>[[User talk:Lojbanist|Styrofoam is not made from kittens.]]</sup> 00:03, 23 December 2018 (UTC)}}
