=== [[Talk:Cynric#rfc_1A54549|Talk:Cynric]] expired 2018-12-24 00:01 ===
* Id: 1A54549
* User: Urselius
* Date: 2018-11-23 23:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|870318785|HIST 870318785}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|875123568|HIST 875123568}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As a prelude to taking this to formal arbitration a discussion on the talk page is usually required - this is it.

User:Cagwinn has on this page, and a number of others, repeatedly placed his personal opinion above that of the relevant scholarship, usually making some plea that certain relevant and entirely reputable books or papers are inadmissible as they are not written by philologists, even though the linguistic point at dispute has direct historical implications, and common sense would imply that scholarly historical references would be entirely appropriate.

In the case of this article, which contains very few citations, he has removed material which is multiply cited to reputable scholarly material. He does not refute the the existence of the scholarly material used, he does not offer alternative views supported by more compelling scholarly citations, he does not choose to add an opposing viewpoint to stand alongside the existing material. No, what he does is remove existing fully referenced material, citing no scholarly material as support for this, merely his own views on the subject. This is own research in its most overt form, and is blatant point of view peddling. Both being entirely antithetical to the spirit and the rules of editing Wikipedia articles. [[User:Urselius|Urselius]] ([[User talk:Urselius|talk]]) 23:02, 23 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Move review#rfc_CA23D49|Wikipedia talk:Move review]] expired 2018-12-24 05:01 ===
* Id: CA23D49
* User: RGloucester
* Date: 2018-11-25 21:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|870601130|POLICY 870601130}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|870601135|PROP 870601135}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|875154839|POLICY 875154839}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|875154843|PROP 875154843}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently, the scope of the move review process is limited to reviewing whether [[WP:RM|requested move]] discussions have been properly closed and executed. The results of discussions that take place as part of the processes called '[[WP:CFD|categories for discussion]]' and '[[WP:RFD|redirects for discussion]]' have in the past been reviewed at [[WP:DRV|deletion review]], even when the relevant discussions did not involve deletion. The awkwardness of this situation has recently become an issue, and so I've opened this RfC. Should the purview of the move review process formally be expanded to include reviews of the closing of renaming discussions that take place at [[WP:CfD]] and [[WP:RfD]], and should the MR, CfD, and RfD pages be updated to clarify the review process for discussions that take part as part of those processes to that effect? [[User:RGloucester|<span style="font-family:Monotype Corsiva;font-size:12pt;color:#000000">RGloucester </span>]] — [[User talk:RGloucester|☎]] 21:32, 25 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Israel#rfc_68EFE96|Talk:Israel]] expired 2018-12-25 11:01 ===
* Id: 68EFE96
* User: Onceinawhile
* Date: 2018-11-25 10:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|870523888|HIST 870523888}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|875300339|HIST 875300339}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have been drawn to this question by [[User:יניב הורון|יניב הורון (Yaniv)]].

The history section is currently 39 paragraphs long, and >100kb in size (about 1/3 of the entire article). It is haphazard in the weight it puts against each of the periods of the region's history (a good visual overview is below). Some examples: we have just two paragraphs on the entire first millenium AD (i.e. from 0AD to 1099AD, including just a single sentence on the development of Christianity in the region), just one sentence on the entire Ottoman period, and just two paragraphs on the mandate period.

{{Timeline of Palestine Sovereign Powers}}

So I have two questions for the community:
# How much weight should the history section of this article have? Is 39 paragraphs '''too much''', '''too little''', or '''about right'''?
# What is a fair and objective way for '''deciding the due weight''' for each time period?

[[User:Onceinawhile|Onceinawhile]] ([[User talk:Onceinawhile|talk]]) 10:21, 25 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Articles for creation#rfc_E154992|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Articles for creation]] expired 2018-12-25 12:02 ===
* Id: E154992
* User: Pkbwcgs
* Date: 2018-11-25 11:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|870528535|PROP 870528535}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|875304650|PROP 875304650}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would like to propose that we delete [[:Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] because this is useless tracking and it already has over 40,000 pages which don't need to be tracked. ArticleWizard is the process that many new editors use to create new articles or new drafts for articles and it is pointless to track this. Two years ago, [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Categories_for_discussion/2016/08/Category:Uploaded_with_UploadWizard Commons got rid of a similar category that tracked images uploaded with UploadWizard]. It is just useless to track pages created with the ArticleWizard. I recently got rid of [[:Category:Unreviewed new articles created via the Article Wizard]] over two weeks ago and that was useless tracking as well. There was a CfD at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2014 February 4#Category:Articles_created_via_the_Article_Wizard]] over four and half years ago and at that time, AfC wasn't that stabilised but now it is. There are over 40,000 pages which don't need to be tracked with this category and 109 useless monthly subcategories of this category that are being tracked at [[:Category:Userspace drafts created via the Article Wizard]] that don't need to be tracked. A lot has change in the last four and a half years and [[:Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] as well as [[:Category:Userspace drafts created via the Article Wizard]] is at a very unmanageable size. We don't need tracking for every single page that is created through the ArticleWizard and that category is just indefinitely growing. Instead of taking it straight to CfD, I decided to open a RfC here and it is big and has been there for over nine years. [[User:Pkbwcgs|Pkbwcgs]] ([[User talk:Pkbwcgs|talk]]) 11:57, 25 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Slavic speakers of Greek Macedonia#rfc_BF2F48A|Talk:Slavic speakers of Greek Macedonia]] expired 2018-12-25 18:01 ===
* Id: BF2F48A
* User: IE linguist
* Date: 2018-11-25 18:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|870575998|LANG 870575998}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|875333930|LANG 875333930}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
The proposal above leads to another one here. If a linguistic article about Slavic dialects of Greece is resumed, to me there would be no sense in the existence of this article, which is '''not''' an ethnic group article, but about a linguistic minority of multiple ethnic groups. There are still no articles about [[Bulgarians in Greece]] and [[Macedonians in Greece]], which are only redirecting links to the article "Slavic speakers of Greek Macedonia". Which makes the topic of this article [[WP:SYNTH|synthesized]].<br>If the article "Slavic dialects of Greece" is created again, should the article "Slavic speakers of Greek Macedonia" be turned into a disambiguation page containing the following new articles?:	<br>
1. Macedonians in Greece<br>
2. Bulgarians in Greece<br>
3. Slavophone Greeks. [[User:IE linguist|IE linguist]] ([[User talk:IE linguist|talk]]) 18:11, 25 November 2018 (UTC)}}

* Id: ECA9CDE

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_9B4CA4B|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2018-12-26 04:01 ===
* Id: 9B4CA4B
* User: Tornado chaser
* Date: 2018-12-12 15:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|873340349|BIO 873340349}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|873340355|POLICY 873340355}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|873340358|PROP 873340358}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|877894780|BIO 877894780}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|877894785|POLICY 877894785}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|877894786|PROP 877894786}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The use of [https://sciencebasedmedicine.org/ sciencebasedmedicine.org] (hereafter referred to as SBM) as a source has been discussed in various contexts[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Biographies_of_living_persons/Noticeboard#Science-based_medicine_as_a_source_for_negative_BLP_content][https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Biographies_of_living_persons/Archive_44#RfC:_The_intersection_of_BLPSPS_and_PSCI_restated][https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_247#sciencebasedmedicine.org][https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_202#Harriet_A._Hall_criticizing_Michael_Greger][https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Michael_Greger/Archive_2#Request_for_comments_on_SBM_source][https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_141#Film_review_by_David_Gorski_at_ScienceBasedMedicine.org_of_Gabriel_Cousens_documentary_Simply_Raw][https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_187#Neuromuscular_scientist's_blog_as_an_RS_on_religious_practices_-_Reiki_as_pseudoscience] but if/when it may be used as a source is still debated, a particular point of contention is whether SBM is a [[WP:SPS|self published source]]. Note that under wikipedia policy self published sources (SPS) and reliable sources (RS) are not mutually exclusive, SPS may be considered reliable if published by an expert in the field being discussed, but regardless of expertise SPS may '''never''' be used as a source for statements about living persons (other than the author of the SPS), see [[WP:BLPSPS]]. 

So the questions are: Is SBM reliable as a source? And are articles on SBM never, sometimes or always self published sources? Note that this RfC is NOT about whether to change any policies, only about when(if ever), under current policy, SBM can be used as a source. [[User:Tornado chaser|Tornado chaser]] ([[User talk:Tornado chaser|talk]]) 15:34, 12 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Help talk:Citation Style 1#rfc_7DE34CB|Help talk:Citation Style 1]] expired 2018-12-27 16:01 ===
* Id: 7DE34CB
* User: Izno
* Date: 2018-11-27 15:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|870882474|POLICY 870882474}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|870882479|TECH 870882479}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|870882483|PROP 870882483}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|875580767|POLICY 875580767}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|875580771|TECH 875580771}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|875580774|PROP 875580774}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Right now, {{noping|Citation bot}} removes publisher and location in {{tl|cite journal}}. Proponents of this removal state that this is recommended by nearly every style guide under the belief that there is little value to the information. 

However:

* Several recent threads at [[User talk:Citation bot]] indicate that removing the parameters is unexpected at-best and believed to be detrimental at worst;
* "nearly every style guide" is not [[WP:MOS|our style guide]]
* Removing them does not respect the consensus in [[Module:Citation/CS1]], which is to provide the parameters in cite journal.

This RFC seeks [[WP:CCC|consensus]] for the following questions:

# Should Citation bot continue to remove these data?
# Is there consensus for this removal, {{em|anywhere}}, by {{em|anyone}}?
# Should we continue to support these parameters in [[Module:Citation/CS1]] for {{tl|cite journal}}? <s>If we continue to support these parameters, should we:</s>
## <s>Support them only in metadata without display;</s>
## <s>Display them only without support in the metadata;</s>
## <s>Status quo, which is both to support them in the metadata and display them?</s>

--[[User:Izno|Izno]] ([[User talk:Izno|talk]]) 15:59, 27 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject National Register of Historic Places/Style guide#rfc_FEB8E67|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject National Register of Historic Places/Style guide]] expired 2018-12-29 02:02 ===
* Id: FEB8E67
* User: Power~enwiki
* Date: 2018-11-29 01:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|871120948|STYLE 871120948}}

For instance, there are many buildings on the National Register with the official name "First Baptist Church". In cases like this, it is common practice to append "(City, State)" to the official title to distinguish it from all the other First Baptist Churches.}}  Should this be amended so "(State)" disambiguation is preferred when it is unambiguous? === [[Talk:Paul Ryan#rfc_92DC8CB|Talk:Paul Ryan]] expired 2018-12-29 19:01 ===
* Id: 92DC8CB
* User: Nevermore27
* Date: 2018-12-13 23:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|874107780|HIST 874107780}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|875894637|BIO 875894637}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|875894645|POL 875894645}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|878094411|BIO 878094411}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|878094415|HIST 878094415}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|878094422|POL 878094422}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This would affect multiple pages but since Ryan is the current speaker I thought this might be a better place to start. In short: should Paul Ryan be counted as the 54th Speaker or the 62nd? News sources seem to disagree: [https://www.wsj.com/articles/paul-ryan-elected-the-houses-62nd-speaker-1446130384] [https://www.marketwatch.com/story/paul-ryan-elected-the-houses-62nd-speaker-2015-10-29][https://www.salon.com/2015/10/29/bye_bye_boehner_paul_ryan_elected_62nd_speaker_of_the_house/][https://mashable.com/2015/10/29/paul-ryan-speaker-house/#lYQs5DQBF8qJ] say 62nd, [https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/house-gop-ready-to-make-paul-ryan-speaker] [https://www.politico.com/story/2015/10/ryan-elected-house-speaker-215342] say 54th. Ryan is the 54th ''person'' to be Speaker, but several speakers served two or more non-consecutive terms ([[Frederick Muhlenberg]], [[Henry Clay]], [[John W. Taylor (politician)]], [[Sam Rayburn]] and [[Joseph W. Martin Jr.]]), including the next likely Speaker, Nancy Pelosi, so there have been 62 distinct terms of the Speakership.

In short, should Paul Ryan be counted as the '''54th''' or '''62nd''' Speaker? '''[[User:Nevermore27|<span style="color: #660198">Nevermore27</span>]]''' ([[User talk:Nevermore27|talk]]) 23:39, 13 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Paul Ryan#rfc_440932E|Talk:Paul Ryan]] expired 2018-12-29 19:01 ===
* Id: 440932E
* User: Snooganssnoogans

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the text in bold be added to this paragraph?:

* The Congressional Leadership Fund (CLF), a super PAC, has been closely linked and aligned with Ryan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/15/us/politics/terrorism-midterms-advertising.html|title=Attack Ads Against Some Democrats Try to Portray Them as Terrorists|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/paul-ryans-super-pac-cancels-ads-backing-some-incumbent-house-republicans-1538165399|title=Paul Ryan’s Super PAC Cancels Ads Backing Some Incumbent House Republicans|last=Epstein|first=Reid J.|date=2018-09-28|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5336902/congressional-leadership-fund-fundraising/|title=This Republican Super PAC Raised $51 Million to Try and Save the Party's House Majority|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-10-24}}</ref> Ryan has directed major GOP donors towards the CLF.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/09/20/gop-super-pac-enters-five-new-house-races-after-adding-million-hold-ryans-seat/|title=GOP super PAC enters five new House races after adding $1.5 million to hold Ryan’s seat|last=|first=|date=|website=Washington Post|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-24}}</ref> The CLF has a reputation for running race-baiting ads.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/oct/25/midterm-attack-ads-five-most-bigoted-divisive-republicans-democrat-videos|title=Five of the most bigoted and divisive political ads from the 2018 midterms|last=Wolfson|first=Sam|date=2018-10-25|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> In ''The Guardian''<nowiki/>'s ranking of the five most bigoted ads during the 2018 election campaign, four of the five were ads by the CLF.<ref name=":7" /> In 2018, the CLF was described as "the highest-spending super PAC seeking to sway House races in the upcoming midterms."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2018/10/16/fact-check-campaign-ads-leading-gop-pac-misleading/1660022002/|title=Fact check: Campaign ads from leading GOP PAC misleading|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en}}</ref> '''During the 2018 mid-term elections. CLF produced a number of false ads, including two that falsely linked two Democratic candidates with terrorists. In one ad, the CLF depicted an African-American Rhodes scholar with a Harvard Law degree as a foul-mouthed and "disturbingly radical" rapper, and misrepresented lyrics from his rap career.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/08/31/fact-checking-republican-attack-ads-tight-house-races/|title=Analysis {{!}} Fact-checking Republican attack ads in tight House races|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/22/us/politics/election-ads-immigration-racism.html|title=The Most Inflammatory Ads of the Midterms|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en}}</ref> CLF obtained the unredacted security clearance application of Abigail Spanberger, a former CIA officer and Democratic congressional candidate, and then used it for political purposes. CLF also sent the highly sensitive document to at least one media outlet.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/28/us/politics/cia-officer-house-election-super-pac.html|title=C.I.A. Officer-Turned-Candidate Says PAC Obtained Her Security Application|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en}}</ref> CLF then ran ads trying to link Spanberger to terrorist activity.<ref name=":6" />'''

{{reflist-talk}}

Please indicate whether you '''support''' or '''oppose''' something similar to the above text, along with your reasoning. [[User:Snooganssnoogans|Snooganssnoogans]] ([[User talk:Snooganssnoogans|talk]]) 18:13, 29 November 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox election#rfc_1B879F7|Template talk:Infobox election]] expired 2018-12-30 01:01 ===
* Id: 1B879F7
* User: Levivich
* Date: 2018-11-30 00:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|871280022|POL 871280022}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|875934939|POL 875934939}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
From the template documentation:

<code>seats_before1 ... The seat count before the election, labeled 'current seats' if the election is yet to take place.</code>

<code>seat_change1 ... The change in the number of seats won at the election compared to the previous election.</code>

'''Questions:'''
# Does a vacant seat count as a "seat before" for a party? What if it is in a district that is considered safe? What if RSes generally count a vacant seat as a "party's seat"?
# Should "seat change" be calculated from "last election" or "seats before"? 
# Should "the rules" be the same for all articles, or should there be exceptions for certain elections (based on nation, or type, etc.)? One size fits all?

''Example 1:'' Party A has 100 members in "last election." Two retire, leaving 98 "seats before." In the election, the two seats are filled by Party A candidates, leaving 100 "seats after." Is Party A's "seat change" +2 (from "seats before") or 0 (from "last election")?

''Example 2:'' "Last election" is Party A 100, Party B 100. Two As retire, leaving 98 A / 100 B. In a special election to fill one of those vacancies, Party B wins, "flipping the seat," leaving 98 A / 101 B as "seats before." On Election Day, Party A wins 99 seats, Party B wins 101 seats ("seats after"). Is Party A's "seat change" +1 (99 "seats after" - 98 "seats before") or -1 (100 "last election" - 99 "seats after")?

''Example 3:'' "Last election" is 100 A / 100 B. Each party has two vacancies, leaving 98 A / 98 B. One of the A seats is won by a B candidate in a special election, leaving 98 A / 99 B "seats before." On Election Day, one of the B vacancies flips to A, leaving 100 A / 100 B "seats after." Is "seat change" +2 A, +1 B (98->100, 99->100, from "seats before"), meaning both parties made gains in the election, or is "seat change" 0 A, 0 B (100->100 for both from "last election")? [[User:Levivich|Levivich]] ([[User talk:Levivich|talk]]) 00:52, 30 November 2018 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums#rfc_F99E5ED|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums]] expired 2018-12-30 01:01 ===
* Id: F99E5ED
* User: Levivich
* Date: 2018-11-30 00:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|871293948|POL 871293948}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|875934939|POL 875934939}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is it an {{s|"open election" or}} an "open seat" if an incumbent runs in an early round of the election (''e.g.'' a primary), but no incumbent runs in the final round (''e.g.'' a general election)? For example, if an incumbent runs and loses in a primary, or withdraws after a primary, and there is no incumbent in the general election, is that an "open" election or an "open" seat?) What if the final round has no opponent (as in the case of MA-7 in the recent US House elections)? [[User:Levivich|Levivich]] ([[User talk:Levivich|talk]]) 00:08, 30 November 2018 (UTC)}}
